In Ancient Greek, the word kyaenos was often used for colors on the darker end of the spectrum, including what we now know was violet, black, dark blue, brown, or dark green. Our modern word “cyan,” a greenish blue, comes from this word. Galazio or Kaïlas or Azure which means blue . Just because ancient Greeks called blue by different words doesn’t mean they didn’t see it EXACTLY as we do today. In English, color can function in the opposite way linguistically. Consider the color pink: pink is on the red scale, so if we had no word for pink, it could easily be considered a light red, and we would refer to it as such. Yet, as we have a distinct name for the color pink, we perceive it as a different color than red. Greeks certainly could see the color blue, but they didn’t consider it separate from other shades, such as green, complicating how exactly they perceived the hue. Here is a thing that has been established a long time ago. The retina of a human eye has three cones. One cone is receptive only to red and reflects the other colors, the other one to green, and the last one to blue. That's why the basic primary color for human is RGB, i.e., Red, Green and Blue.  So it's really hard to believe what you have just discussed. Anyway it is interesting. More so, it is entertaining but arguably I can't say it is educational. Additionally, other living things have different numbers of cones in their retinas. Dog has only two so they see few colors while butterflies have more than ten. And finally, regarding the greeks. If you look at some of the old greek frescoes and potteries during the ancient time, meaning B.C., you can find the color blue. One particular example is a pottery with the painting of Ajax and Achilles. Ajax's uniform has the color blue in it.

This reminds me of a discussion I've had where what we believe is true (as in widely acceptable) is largely shaped by what we've been taught and have been exposed to. A key factor in this is language. When someone points to an object, and tells me that it's a bed, we perceive that the widely acceptable truth is that it's a bed. Yet, this isn't the case. Those who speak different languages have different terms for it. People in other countries use different words for the same thing, even if those words may still be English. For example, as an Indian, I know that my family in India would have called it a cot in the past. Nowadays, the wide exposure to western media has definitely changed that, leading them to use the word bed more often.

Let's look back at just English now. Let's say someone believes that dogs can only be dogs if they are black. But they are then confronted with a golden retriever. This is similar to a color distinction as in this video. They may think, "Well then, this creature that appears to be a dog must not be a dog after all. Dogs must be black, and although this looks like a dog, it isn't black. Therefore, this isn't a dog." If the English language was constructed as such. If we as humans didn't have any sort of construct for what a "species" is, and drew distinctions within species and classified them as different animals, then that individual is very much correct. Their world simply uses different language and categorizes golden retrievers and black labs as different animals. They aren't both dogs, because the generalization "dog" doesn't exist.

So back to the Greeks. They simply didn't have a term for the word "blue". So, they used its generalization. It's not like they can't see that it's lighter than black just like it's not that they can't see that a black labrador is different from a golden retriever. It's because they don't have this distinctions in their language that all the distinctions fall under the same umbrella term. So blue, just becomes black. And that is their widely accepted truth. It's not that they can't see blue. It's just that what to us is "blue", is their black.

That's not quite right: the word cyan originates back to Ancient Greece; we used the word κύανο (EN: keeano) to describe what we thought was "key blue": the color of our sea. Everything in blue was thought to be a shade of what it's considered to be 'turquoise' by today's standards. The modern Greek word μπλέ (EN: bleh) is of French / Breton origin, and was adopted just about a hundred years ago, thus not found in our ancient Greek scriptures.

This is such a huge untrue fact and a misconception! Foreign scolars of Homer and ancient Greek language, somehow got the idea that ancient Greeks didn't have a word for blue. Additionally to that, Homer describes in both Heliad and Odyssey the sea as "wine like in face", which they interpreted as "ancient Greeks didn't have a word for blue ". So let's disect that. 1. Homer was using poetic language, BUT, in some parts of Greece when the weather is bad the sea gets a blue-reddish tint like face. So, he was being poetic and literally describing the color of the sea on a "bad day".
2. Ancient Greeks used to mix seawater in their wines, and drink it. They believed it was the right way of drinking it and very recently, when scientists have replicated the process, which is extensively described in ancient Greek texts, have it done just right, it gives the wine a blueish tint.
3. Ancient Greek language, and modern one, have a lot of words for describing different shades of blue. So, there is not just one word for it. There are a lot, depending on the shade, γαλάζιο, γλαύκο, ουρανί, ιώδες, κυανό. Many times though they would use the color that the sky or the sea reminded them of, in a poetic manner, as we modern Greeks do. We say for instance that "The sea has a golden color" when the sunrays hit it.
4. Ancient Greeks used blue and similar shades a lot, as found in pottery, wall art, marble statues and mosaics. BUT, because of the use of costly pigments blue was an expensive color to use, so often it was swapped for something less expensive.
5. There are many scenes in walls and frescoes in Minoan Crete especially, in the isle of Santorini and elsewhere, with the blue color. Thus, how on earth could they be colorblind on a color they chose to express vividly?

I have reason to believe this information is not entirely accurate. Can't speak for other civilizations, but Hebrews were told to dye the fringes of their clothes (tzitzit) into blue (tekhelet). It's a color mentioned pretty often in the Torah (and the Bible), as it had MANY other applications.
This second part is more hearsay, but I am told that dye was derived from small marine creatures much like snails which could be crushed under sunlight which would chemically react with the UV rays turning blue, which is what Hebrews used for their dyes, or it could be crushed in the dark, which would produce a deep purple color that other peoples in the area typically used as a "royal" color.

One direct example of defining colors and distinguishing them more easily in the English language that I like is the color brown. Chinese has the word “blue” for more than 2000 years ago @@

青(blue pigment)，取之於藍(blue plant)，而勝於藍
The idiom literally says the blue pigment 青 is made with a blue plant 蓼「藍」, but it’s bluer than the plant; which would be interpreted as “student is having better accomplishments than the teacher”

The word 青 actually groups blue and green at first, and is later also used by other languages influenced by Chinese to describe both colours, and those languages retain that use until today

While the word 藍, originally used as the name of the plant, is later used for describing the colour blue specifically instead, and become a more common way to describe “blue” and 青 would be using for blues with a greenish hue or even light green

Given those circumstances, we still have some people calling some more bluish blues as 青, but that depends on the cultural backgrounds and personal preferences

So just like the Japanese, for certain objects when people use the word 青, like the traffic light or the sky, we would understand the actual colour despite the word by the context

For the word 蒼, it originally means black or very very dark blue, and ancient Chinese would substitute this word for the Sky or the Sea (maybe they created that word at night lol), so when this word is used, it’s usually linked with the sky, and the meaning has gradually shifted to imply a certain blue with depth to it (less dark as the word was used before) or even “pale” if conjugated with the word “white” when describing how a person looks like

So when I’m reading a text in Spring and Autumn period (the time of Confucius), I would know the word 蒼 should mean black or some blues that is very close to black, but if I’m reading a text that is of a later or even modern period, I would understand the colour as a darker sky blue or the sea colour

Same words could have various meanings and those meanings changed overtime, so I’m not sure why people are arguing over that, just have background checks on the time, place and overall context of the text was written and you could guess which meaning it is implying

fact that blue had a significant presence in INDIAN culture for thousands of years.
Ancient Indian texts have mentioned of color blue “neel” and also recognized that a poisoned person turns blue in color. Lord Shiva was also known in mythical texts as neel-kanth ( the one with the blue throat) when he consumed poison. Lord Vishnu was blue and most of his Avatars(Sanskrit word for “a different form in the same universe”) were considered to be blue in skin tone like Rama & Krishna. So color is mentioned in historical texts. Blue dye in natural form is made from the Neel plant (the indigo plant) in the ancient Indus Valley civilization of Harappa. Again blue may be an ancient color. There is no certain way to prove the color sequence theory presented here.

This isn't unique to ancient languages and peoples. Russian has separate words for blue and grey-blue. That doesn't mean that we can't see grey-blue or that we can't see that blue and grey-blue are different. The only difference is that to us, grey-blue is a shade of blue while to native Russian-speakers it is a separate color.

And on a minor archaeological note, the Ancient Greeks did have and use blue pigments. As mentioned, blue pigments were already created by the Ancient Egyptians, and the Greeks just got it from there. And just like the Ancient Egyptians and Romans, they generally seem to have considered blue to be a shade of green. They did however have several words for different shades of what we would consider blue. There is "glaukos" for green-blue and grey-blue, "kuaneos" (hence our word cyan) for the color of corroded copper and "huakinthos" (hyacinthine) for a purplish shade of blue. They knew blue colors just as well as we do, they just didn't see "blue" as a separate color category.

Modern Greek has the distinction between light blue and normal blue, which does not occur in Western Europe, but occurs in eastern Europe. Many people see light blue as a different colour than true blue, which is closer to black. Greek by the time of the Hellenistic period definitely had the term blue. Earlier colour terms were much broader, just like in any other early culture. Even in modern times, many languages still don’t have the distinction between green and blue or don’t have true terms for those colours at all. Samoan for example doesn’t have a real word for green or blue, they do exist nowadays, but they are made up recently.

There are two different words for blue and light blue in Slavic languages ("siniy" for blue and "goluboy" for light blue in Russian, for instance), so we feel and recognize them as two different colors. Although, of course, we understand that these are variations of the same color. This is the same story as with red and pink.

It’s most likely that blue was just categorized as other colors. The most common instance where we see blue categorized as it’s own color is in countries of romantic origin. This can lead us to presume that as the romans spread and found new territories with new things, say Egypt with their blue pigments, they made it a distinct color so they could identify it as valuable. Blue as a color has very little sources we can get pigment from.
You may be thinking “wait, didn’t the Greeks also establish trade chains with Egyptians?” And you’d be correct. The reason for this change in distinction of the color blue could be linked to what Greece traded and what Rome traded.
Greece mainly traded for food and luxury items such as wine and pottery. Their source of indigo dye came from India and their source Egyptian blue dye came from Egypt, obviously. They would use this dye in paintings such as the wall paintings of Knossos, in Crete. Perhaps what they did instead of value it for its rarity and use as a dye for clothing (often wore by higher powers, as seen in later civilizations such as Britain and France), but they simply used it as a hue of another color used to paint.
This weirdly reflects and conflicts to the ways romans used blue. Blue, in roman times, wasn’t a color or hue, but an idea. Blue was used to establish character and political/intellectual status. They perhaps saw it as yet again, another shade of black or grey or green.
As the word progressed, the color blue would finally be named as the color “blue”. Blue comes from the Middle English word bleu, which comes from the French word bleu, which has Germanic origin as blao, meaning lustrous. This shows how several countries began to recognize blue as its own color due to trade spreading the term over the course of hundreds of years.
In heldary (meaning something related to rank and status in government/military) blue is known as azure. Russia, even though it and its language don’t originate from Rome, has multiple names for shades of blue. In Russian, the word for light blue can also mean yellow, light green, or gray.
The Spanish language also strangely follows this weird pattern where there are multiple words for blue, most corresponding to certain hues. They, however, do not have multiple meanings like Russian blues.
Let’s look at Japan now. Japan, like the Himba people of the Namibia, closely associates blue with green, making them one in the same. In Japan, trash cans and recycling bins are either green or blue, with no distinction need for distinction between the two.
So what’s the conclusion? It all depends on what the civilization did with blue, what they associated with it, and if blue had some sort of importance in their culture. Blue has always existed, and no amount of brain work can make it indistinct. It’s not the brain that decides whether blue is it’s own color, it’s the people.

As someone who studied linguistics, I’d like to point out that even if Greeks did not have a word for blue (which is debatable), linguistic determinism (i.e: the theory that if a language lacks a word for a concept, then language users cannot comprehend or articulate the concept) has been disproven. There are plenty of existing languages that do not have words for certain colours, but users are able to differentiate between the colours anyway. So if anyone’s argument for the Ancient Greek not seeing blue is because they didn’t have a word, it’s just not that simple.

Language does however affect the way we think (this is called linguistic relativity and it is fascinating, let me tell you) and the latter case described in the video is much more likely- there wasn’t a common word for blue (still debatable!), so people would be less adept at articulating and recognising the colour, because it simply doesn’t have a nice category for the brain to fit the concept into. Like trying to describe teal, or decide if teal looks more like green or blue if you don’t have the word ‘teal’ in your lexicon. So yeah, this comment is just to clarify things for anyone who thinks the Greeks were walking around colourblind to blue. I also love how everyone is suddenly horny for linguistics in the comments, although I feel the need to point out all these theories (linguistic relativity and linguistic determinism) are not new at all, but I’m glad they’re garnering some mainstream interest.

When referring to the Bible, you must go back to the Hebrew language to fully understand the words used within it's pages.

Blue: “Tekelet” is the Hebrew word for Blue. It is also found in the Bible to mean purple (Ezekiel 23:6) or violet (Jeremiah 10:9). Blue is a symbol for heaven and the Word of God. Among the Hebrews purple was the YHWH color (Exodus 24:10; Ezekiel 1:26). When Moses was in God’s presence before receiving the Ten Commandments, he described the pavement under His feet as being bright as the blue sky (Exodus 24:10).

“Tekelet” was the color given for priest’s clothing, and their hems (Exodus 28:5-6). Blue and purple, scarlet and gold, were the colors of the fixtures in the tabernacle (Exodus 35 -39). Also, purple, the dress of kings, was linked with royalty and majesty (Judges 8:26; Esther 8:15; Daniel 5:7, 16, 29)

In Old Sundanese poetries, the ocean and leaves were called as héjo. The sky, not surprisingly, was also called héjo. Nowadays, people associate the word héjo more with what we'd call "green", after Malay biru was loaned into the language.

What's more interesting is that biru has an unclear etymology. Most people I've talked to think it came from a European language (perhaps Dutch or some other colonizers' language), but when I searched for it in dictionaries, I found out that Old Javanese, which had developed prior to the arrival of Europeans, had it too. It's strange, since in old Malay poetries, the word biru wasn't used, but hijau (associated with "green" now) was. Biru was used more commonly after the Europeans came.

My grandpa and grandma are prime examples of intergenerational color-seeing differences. So I have this pair of sandals, which I would say are biru (blue). However, both of them call the sandals ijo, a word oftenly associated with "green" for people of my generation. We also have a handkerchief at home; I call it ungu (purple), but they call it abang (red). Another fun fact is that the colors I say and the colors they say are in different languages; I speak in Indonesian, and they speak in Javanese.

I want to ask something.  I am profoundly deaf since birth.  I wasn't diagnosed until I was 7.5 years old, after I had failed kindergarten AND first grade.  I was put into a school for mental retardation until the diagnosis was made during the summer.  Given that, I learned to remember colors not by words, but by the sensations I felt inside when I would see colors.  Different colors would manifest in different parts of my head and my throw for a few colors.  Blue is felt from the top of my head downward.  Purple has a presence that is felt in the center of my mouth and part of my nasal cavity.  Red is the one that I feel in my throat, towards the back and fading both upward behind the velar flap and downward into my lungs.  Yellow seems to be felt behind my nose and cheeks.  Green seems to be felt along my palate.  Black is felt everywhere, inside me and outside me.  White, I can't describe.  I also see shapes and textures in a different way.  I feel the sharp points of a square, cube, triangle, etc. spatially within.  I feel the texture of an asphalt road in the back of my throat.  Wood texture, I can't describe.  Smooth glass is felt around my cheeks, as is a round shape or a spherical shape.  Native American or Indian beadwork, the appearance of the beads is felt behind both eyes and at the same time, I feel the texture of the smooth beads and the colors.

Video ignores the fact that the ancient Minoans, who predated the ancient Greeks in the same area and who culturally influenced the ancient Greeks to a very significant extent, used blue in many of their frescos, and used blue very accurately (ie, they painted things blue which we see today as blue). Homer (who was reputed to be blind) was using "wine-dark sea" to describe the darkness of the sea, not its color, it's likely the phrase was an idiom, and one that makes a lot more sense than a lot of color-based English idioms, like "paint the town red" and "green with envy." This "ancient Greeks didn't see blue/saw blue differently" is junk science that has been around a while but ignores quite a lot of evidence that contradicts it to try to prove its point.

It is more that blue varies in nature  and can best be described more often with its secondary attributes. Ex: Some bodies of water while technically blue are described as teal..(perhaps leaning towards green) that is impacted on clarity of the water. If the water is very clear and technically blue but it against a yellow or beige sea bed it will appear green..even more so if the shade of light being used to illuminate the area is of a more yellow wavelength.

The idea that language trains our brain to be more adept at differentiating is at once both obvious and also utterly mind-blowing!

I've heard the Innuit peoples ("Eskimos") have many more words for snow than other languages and if you think about how many different types of snow there are (powdery snow, wet snow, compressed dense snow, snow that falls but doesn't stick, large snow flakes, small snow flakes, snow that it soft on top but solid ice underneath, snow that is coated with a layer of ice but powdery underneath, etc) it makes sense that people who are constantly surrounded by snow, and thus their daily lives are affected by differences in that snow, would need to develop vocabulary to differentiate the varieties.

Again, seems obvious, but it has INCREDIBLE possibilities across the board!

The idea that the language affects the brain as much as the brain affects the language is the basis for a lot of talk therapy. In some forms of therapy clients are taught to identify emotions and attach names to them. Naming the emotion helps the client identify and distinguish it from other sometimes broader emotions. For example embarrassment, anxiety, and fear all can trigger the fight or flight response in a person. Folks with limited emotional vocabulary generally describe this as anger (or "getting pissed") because their body is preparing for a physical encounter. Through the introduction of emotional vocabulary and assistance naming the underlying emotions a client begins to be able to distinguish between emotional triggers in the same way the video describes distinguishing between colors. 🤯🤯 Mind blowing.

This is not entirely true. Ancient Indian texts have mentions of color blue “neel” and also recognized that a poisoned person turns blue in color. Lord shiva also known in mythical texts  as neel-kanth ( the one with blue throat) when he consumed poison. Lord Vishnu was blue and most of his Avatars(Sanskrit word for “a different form in the same universe”)  that were considered to be blue in skin tone like Rama & Krishna.  So the color is mentioned in historical texts. Blue dye in natural form is made from the Neel plant (the indigo plant) in the ancient Indus Valley civilization of Harappa. Again blue may be an ancient color. There is no certain way to prove the color sequence theory presented here.

Hi, a Greek guy here. Actually there is a Homeric word "γλαυκή" used as female adjective at 16.34 to describe the sea, and at 18.39 used as a name for one of the Nereids (sea nymphs). This word means silver blue, and gives the adjective "γλαυκώπις" to describe Athena's eyes. Another word that you can find in later texts such as Aristotle's, is "κυανόν" which is used up to today as a more archaic version of the word "μπλε" which means blue.

In Slovenian language the book word for blue is "modra/o", in spoken language we use archaic "plava/o", interesting, I was surprised about this as a child, is that we use word "plava/o" for blond or bright hair (but not grey bright).
For sky blue we use word "sinja/e", usually just when talking about really bright sky or light blue eyes. Otherwise ordinary day sky color is basic word for all shades of color blue "modra/o", for night sky we usually use black "črna/o" (chrna/o) or dark "temno".
Interestingly the wise man in Slovenian is literary called the blue man, what suggest the connection with Indian philosophies and chackras, where the mind and knowleadge chackra is blue. We mustent forget that hindi is part of Indoeuropean langue family, with almost all languages languages in Europe, except Estonian, Hungarian, Finnish, Maltese, Basque. You're not as smart as you think you are. Ancient greeks COULD see blue. Just because there wasn't one of our contemporary terms for blue, doesn't mean they didn't see it. A better title for this video would have been "Why ancient greeks didn't understand blue, and how this lead to their generally not acknowledging it." When they looked at the waters of the Mediterranean, they saw exactly what we see, they just looked at it in terms of how it related to more common colors, rather than defining it as ts own color. For centuries, due to it's rarity, blue was considered a shade of black, that's all. Primarily because blue pigment was virtually non existent, until the introduction of "ultramarine." in the middle ages. You'll see that once there is a reasonably available source of blue, societies produce a word for it. Why, because seeing something on a regular basis, versus rarely ever, means talking about it. Talking about it means producing a word for it. That word soon becomes common knowledge, and it starts showing up in writings. People were able to see it all along, they just didn't often talk or write about it, because they rarely saw it. So, got news for ya, the ancient Greeks could see blue just fine...

Γλαύκο and κυανό are the words used by Homer and later authors to describe the color of the sea and sky. Today we still use them to describe light and dark blue. Of course κυανό (ky-a-no) is cyan which as we know has shades ranging from green to blue so I can see how the theory you're explaining makes sense, I just think it had already entered the language by the time Homer, a very famous blind man, composed his work.

The other thing to take into account is that Homer was not a war zone reporter. He does not describe many things exactly as they are seen but adds lyricism and metaphors for effect. For example he describes the sea "dark like wine". That doesn't speak to the colour but to how easy it is to get lost in it, almost like intoxication.

You are absolutely right on the order colors manifest in languages though.

The sky isn't blue. It's cyan, and blue isn't blue, it's indigo. Cyan used to be blue and now it's not. We changed words at some point - and are still ambiguous on it. I wonder whether our ability for object permanence reinforced the concept of blue being a lighter shade of black. The thought process being: The sky at night is black. During the day it's still sky, but lighter, so it's a lighter shade of black.

In all reality, only 3 true colors exist. Red, Blue, and Yellow. All the rest of the colors we know are mixed and can be created using different combinations of those three colors. Adding white or black pigments to them then will create any shades or tints of those colors that we know.

Your underlying premise is completely false. The notion that the ancient Greeks had no word for the color blue is a popular meme that has been around since at least the mid-1800s, but it is not true. The ancient Greeks actually had several different words for blue. Here is a list of all the major ancient Greek color terms and their meanings:

ἐρυθρός (erythrós) means “red,” but especially “deep red” or “crimson.”
κόκκος (kókkos) means “scarlet.”
ῥοδόεις (rhodóeis) means “pink” or “rosy.”, the name of the ancient Greek Cinderella, Rhodopis (Ῥοδῶπις; Rhodôpis), means “rosy-eyed” or “rosy-faced.”
χλωρός (khlōrós) means “bright green,” “greenish yellow,” or “yellow.”
χρύσεος (khrýseos) means “golden.”
ξανθός (xanthós) means “reddish yellow,” “brownish yellow,” or “light brown.” It is the color of Achilleus’s hair. A slave with the name Ξανθίας (Xanthíās), which means “blondie,” appears in many of the comedies of Aristophanes.
γλαυκός (glaukós) means “light gray,” “bluish gray,” or “light blue.” It is the color of Athena’s eyes.
ἀργύρεος (argýreos) means “silver.”
πολιός (poliós) means “dark gray.”
κύανος (kýanos) means “dark blue.”
κυάνεος (kyáneos) also means “dark blue.”
οἶνοψ (oînops) means “wine-looking.” It can be used to describe things that are dark blue, but does not refer to a specific color. It is famously used to describe the sea in the Homeric poems.
πορφύρεος (porphýreos) means “dark blue,” “indigo,” or “purple.”
φοῖνιξ (phoînix) means “crimson” or “deep purple.”
λευκός (leukós) means “white” or “pale.”
μέλας (mélās) means “very dark in color,” “dark brown,” or “black.”

Sorry but this whole thing is a pretty wide stretch supported by more than a few false equivalencies. It's an interesting approach to be sure, but I am not convinced that a difference in linguistic categorization necessarily correlates to a physical difference in perception. A lot of just sounds like semantics being taken too far. I deal with color a lot professionally, and I have no issue perceiving colors despite not memorizing my Pantone guides.

This isn't to say that I wholly disagree however. Yes, if you have more colloquial categorization for things then yes, one could say that you see something differently because paying attention to it is more normal for you than someone else. You're dedicating more mental bandwidth to the distinction. Think of a collector. For me, it's antique firearms which for most will all look the same, especially if they are in the same family but to me, small differences to you can be quite large to me. But this does not mean you cannot spot differences between families despite you or I not having any explicit words to separate them. Same with that blue circle in the ring of green. Just because the tribe may not have an explicit term as they might with the different greens does not mean they don't see the stark contrast between the blue dot and green dots.

As a linguist I can tell you that the part about the order of color vocabulary developing is simply untrue, but remains a popular myth. Berlin and Kay first did research into the area, but heavily skewed their own experiments by presenting the stimulus in the form of color swatches that were already delimited by the relevant English terms. Doing so assumes that that the English way of categorizing colors is more or less an objective truth/ "true" reflection of reality. However, framing it this way glosses over many culturally specific and unique taxonomies. For example, Hanunoo would be classified as having only four categories: DARK, including what English would identify as Black and Blue, LIGHT, including English White, RED including english Red, and then a final category referring to both English Yellow and Green. However, a closer examination of the internal system of color classification in the language on its own terms, rather than in foreign terms imposed on it, reveals that the actual cultural taxonomy has to do with LIGHT/DARK and DRY(desiccated)/WET(fresh), which is totally missed if we just try to overlay the English terms. Works like Berlin and Kay's color taxonomies seemed to forget that English taxonomies are culturally subjective, rather than objective reflections of a single truth. Thus the best they could hope to do was overly one particular cultural taxonomy to others with which it may or may not be compatible. Also, Counter example, to "blue" always coming last: in Osage, the term for English blue is older than the one for English green, and the GREEN term is derived from the BLUE one. BLUE can be simply translated as "blue", whereas GREEN is "grassy-blue".

Incorrect information regarding ancient Indian civilization. One of the most popular blues is “Indigo” which is obviously named after its country of origin, India. More than 5,000 years ago, our ancestors in the ancient Indus valley used the blue dye derived from the Indigofera Tinctoria plant to dye their clothes. 
In Shilpashastra (written prior to 6th century CE), a form of Bhairava (one of the eight manifestations of Caṇḍa, Indian avatar) is called as Pralayāntaka (प्रलयान्तक). When depicting Pralayāntaka according to traditional iconographic rules (śilpaśāstra), one should depict him (and other forms of Caṇḍa) having a blue color and good looks; he should carry agni, śakti, gadā and kuṇḍa. The word Śilpaśāstra refers to an ancient Hindu science of arts and crafts, dealing with subjects such as painting, sculpture and iconography. Shilpashastra (शिल्पशास्त्र, śilpaśāstra) represents the ancient Indian science (shastra) of creative arts (shilpa) such as sculpture, iconography and painting. Closely related to Vastushastra (architecture), they often share the same literature.
Hence, though blue or black/blue has been a known color-story in India (as inscribed in Vedic references and epics), in the western world blue has been introduced much later. Mostly, due to the lack of references and difficulty in the production of blue dyes or pigments.

As a Greek I must say that its true that Greeks didnt have an EXACT word for blue as most cultures BUT the reason isnt exactly the same as with the other cultures as this video implies. When Ancient Greeks were mentioning colors most of the times were not mentioning the actual..colors :) but color names had other meanings! For example when Homer mentioned that the sky was bronze, he meant that it was BRIGHT as bronze, when they mentioned the color cyan (ment dark blue) or glafko (dont know the English word, but meant light blue.. the word glaucoma derives from that word) they were discribing brightness of something "blue" not actual blue colors (although this proves that they had at least two words for two gradiations of blue). Yellow also ment "fresh" or "alive" so they often said that blood was yellow!!! but they only did that because according to the meaning above, yellow was the proper word for them to describe something fresh and alive that gave life. They knew that it was red, but when they said that, yellow was not used as color name anymore. Many statues and walls etc had blue colors so they were using that color a lot as a color (dolphins, sky, sea, dresses, jewlery etc etc it was an important color only for paintings), so it wasnt as rare as this video implies, but had no special meaning for them except in paintings. Simple as that.
The whole point is that color names were not used as.. colors but either as properties of light, meaning, states etc..

Completely false. The notion that the ancient Greeks had no word for the color blue is a popular meme that has been around since at least the mid-1800s, but it is not true. The ancient Greeks actually had several different words for blue. Here is a list of all the major ancient Greek color terms and their meanings:

ἐρυθρός (erythrós) means “red,” but especially “deep red” or “crimson.”
κόκκος (kókkos) means “scarlet.”
ῥοδόεις (rhodóeis) means “pink” or “rosy.” As I discuss in this article I wrote, the name of the ancient Greek Cinderella, Rhodopis (Ῥοδῶπις; Rhodôpis), means “rosy-eyed” or “rosy-faced.”
χλωρός (khlōrós) means “bright green,” “greenish yellow,” or “yellow.”
χρύσεος (khrýseos) means “golden.”
ξανθός (xanthós) means “reddish yellow,” “brownish yellow,” or “light brown.” It is the color of Achilleus’s hair. A slave with the name Ξανθίας (Xanthíās), which means “blondie,” appears in many of the comedies of Aristophanes.
γλαυκός (glaukós) means “light gray,” “bluish gray,” or “light blue.” It is the color of Athena’s eyes.
ἀργύρεος (argýreos) means “silver.”
πολιός (poliós) means “dark gray.”
κύανος (kýanos) means “dark blue.”
κυάνεος (kyáneos) also means “dark blue.”
οἶνοψ (oînops) means “wine-looking.” It can be used to describe things that are dark blue, but does not refer to a specific color. It is famously used to describe the sea in the Homeric poems.
πορφύρεος (porphýreos) means “dark blue,” “indigo,” or “purple.”
φοῖνιξ (phoînix) means “crimson” or “deep purple.”
λευκός (leukós) means “white” or “pale.”
μέλας (mélās) means “very dark in color,” “dark brown,” or “black.”
As you can see, the ancient Greeks possessed a rich vocabulary of words for different colors and they had several words meaning “blue.”

The myth that the ancient Greeks did not have a word for “blue” seems to have arisen from the fact that they did not have a single word that meant “blue” in exactly the same way the English word blue does.

This is not all that convincing...sorry. Certainly the historical record requires the existence of a word before we can expect to see that word in use, but I would chalk this up to poor or incomplete translation, before I'd jump to the conclusion that either the color, or the humans were so different from us that they didn't notice the color itself.

Which is more likely? That people didn't notice the color, or that we misinterpreted the word for this color? This seems like a much easier question to answer.

Finally, there is one other possible explanation for the apparent absence of "blue" in the historical record. It's possible that the sunlight we see today is different from the sunlight experienced in the past. A scenario I find more likely, and one that might be explained by a changing of the atmosphere that lets the light in, in the first place. Perhaps the big filter in the sky is letting in more blue light waves than ever before.

From what I learned long ago is that the ocean actually gets it's color from the sky. In places where the sky's are almost always grey, the color of the ocean is dark and grey. The old Norse did actually have a word for blue in the sagas. It's a conmon misconception and mistranslation to say that it's black instead. As Dr. Jackson Crawford points out, the words Blur (the direct line to blue) and Svartr are used separately. Blur is used for ravens, which is the common reason people believe it to mean black. But that's a cultural interpretation, because if you look closely at a raven their feathers actually have a blue tint, and against the stark whites and blacks of Scandanavia the chance that that stands out is higher.

A more compelling case is the fact that there are two eyecolors "blur and svartr". Blur is blue, and Svarter (black) was used for brown eyes.

In Japan, the word of green came far later than blue. Aoi, blue, was used for shades of green and often still is, like in stop lights. The word Midori for green is newer. Not to mention that they actually view the ocean as green as well, but the word for blue is used because it means it. Now it is a possibility Aoi meant green first and the meaning changed, but it doesn't quite line up with the rest of the trends.

I feel like a lot of these old linguistics/anthropological studies are quite steeped in cultural bias, incorrect translations, and assumptions that every culture must "progress" forwards towards Western ideals (which they don't) and therefore must follow this set path. While the neurological differences of language are cool, much of our anthropological history is practically useless with how abused it's been.

If you are trained to value a distinction, like pink vs red, you will more quickly jump to that distinction as being significant or relevant to the question. Not that you see it as a color that is more or less different. If you “think” in your spoken language you will be better are articulating your thoughts, but quite limited at understanding the world and solving problems.
Also you just don’t need the color blue in the primitive world. You just say the color of the sky. And your almost never need to say it.

When making model kits as a teenager, Japanese planes were described (in English translations made by the Japanese) as having a red light on one win-tip and a blue light on the other wing-tip.
There are a very few colour photographs of Japanese WWII planes, and the lights are (in a small number of these pictures) visible as red or green (sometimes pictures are reversed on publication).

There has been an international convention on coloured lights carried by ships for quite a while (agreed before WWII) and it stipulates red and green side-lights to show which side of a ship is which. This was carried over into aircraft.

So at some time the Japanese had both ships and planes with red / green side lights, but still called green blue well into the 1980s in model kits instructions.

I realized this when studying Asian languages. In Japanese, 青い "aoi" is both green and blue. The sky, the ocean, grass, and the traffic light that tells you to go are all 青い. There's another Japanese word for green, 緑 "midori", but it doesn't map well onto the English word. The Japanese word for pink is just ピンク "pinku", a loan word from English.

Thai, by contrast, has more colors than English. It has pink, สีชมพู "sī champū", which is not a shade of red, and Thai has two words for blue, สีน้ำเงิน "sī namngeun", which is darker blue, and สีฟ้า "sī fā", which is to blue what pink is to red.

Thing is, in Greek you don't have one name for that color. So how can you make a video on this subject when you are not familiar with the language? Not necessarily to be fluent in Greek, but at least find out the basics. In Greek the clear blue sky is not blue (μπλε), but galanOs (γαλανός) which is the "light blue" shade or "sky blue" if you wish. A person does have blue (μπλέ) eyes, but galanA (γαλανά) being the plural, female gender for the word galanOs. I capitalized the last letter which is were the stress goes when you say the word.

The ancient Egyptians had numerous words for blue. The colour (iwen) of the sea, the Nile river, the sky, cornflowers, the gems of lapis lazuli and turquoise, etc - all came under the general heading of 'irtyu' and 'khesbedj'. Distinctions were made between light and dark blue.  Red was 'desher' which included variations of orange. Yellow was 'khenet' and included gold. Brown was 'demy', black was 'kem' and also the ancient Egyptians name for Egypt itself - 'The Black Land' after the rich black silt of the Nile. White was 'hedi' and 'shesep' which included the colour grey. Green was 'wahdj'.

Psychologically, yellow and blue are the first visual experiences that man records since they share the most luminosity with black and white, then it's red and the others. BS, In the KJV Bible, the word 'blue' occurs fifty times, all of which are in the Old Testament. The Hebrew word translated as this color is tekeleth (Strong's Concordance #H8504), which is a reference to the animal from which the dye is obtained. In Japan, they refer to the 'go' stoplight colour as AOI (blue), though they have different word MIDORI which refers to the colour green. The way I've heard it explained is that the older word AOI (A- OH-E) was used to refer to the blue-green colour spectrum, and so isn't technically wrong. So I guess it doesn't break the rule of blue always being labeled last in a language but in this case blue won in the battle to keep the older word AOI over green (MIDORI) which emerged in the language later. It's also confusing why they would use that older colour grouping on a modern piece of technology when MIDORI (green) obviously already existed in the Japanese language upon Japan adopting the use of street signals. There's a lot more to this issue worldwide. See https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue%E2%80%93green_distinction_in_language

If someone is calling honey green and sheep violet, it’s a big obvious sign that those words don’t exclusively mean green or violet. This subject is often misrepresentated because lacking a word doesn’t make the concept impossible to describe, it means nearby words expand to fill its place and more specific terms like light-water-colour or sky-colour are used when necessary. The basic colour terms we’re familiar with are a learned, arbitrary way to split up our colour perception and it is e.g. not accurate to say that the Japanese call blue green and more than it is for Russian-speakers to say we call light-blue dark-blue in English because we don’t have basic colour words for both.

on the topic of colours being more or less a social construct:
brow. picture it, in your mind, the colour brown. look up something on the internet that is brown. a bear, a pool of mud, some wood furniture, anything thats brown works. and now that youve done that: whatever you looked up on the internet, whatever picture of brown you looked at... you didnt see brown, because brown light doesnt exist do your remember EVER seing brown light? nope. but the display on your pc or your phone or tablet or whatever works with light, and you saw something brown on it, how is that possible if there is no brown light? well thats mainly due to the fact that brown innen of itself doesnt exist. its just much more evident when working with light. if you have a program like photoshop etc go to the colour wheel and pick something you would describe as brown. and you realise brown is just a larger section of orange so there is no brown light, only orange light. but that doesnt explain why you could see a brown image on your screen that works on the basis of light. the answer is simple: context. your screen manages to produce the colour brown even though there is no brown light by context. the main issue is that the colour brown is a generally fairly dark, even light brown is significantly darker then most other colours and with a light source you can turn down the brightness so theoretically you would just take an orange light source and turn the brightness down to get brown. but there lies the issue, with that lightsource you will never get a brown light because the light source will always be brighter then the surrounding so you will never have enough contrast to make the light seem brown, but your screen has an incredibly large amounts of light so it can create more elaborate context then just adjusting the brightness of a single light source, thus it can make a brown image
for a more indepth explanation and examples id suggest the video "Brown; color is weird" by technology connections: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wh4aWZRtTwU

Ugh… You can tell this wasn’t written by someone who has actually studied linguistics. This idea that language effects perception like this is sooo outdated. Yes, having a term for something can help you notice it and recognize it, but lacking the word doesn’t mean you are incapable of perceiving or understanding the concept. There are cultures in South America who don’t have number words above three or four. Does that mean they’re incapable of perceiving amounts higher than that? No, their culture just hasn’t needed that precise of counting, yet.

Speakers of languages that don’t differentiate between certain colors aren’t any more or less capable of seeing those colors than any other language’s speakers. It’s a matter of how valuable the distinction is. And the studies that claim people who speak a language that differentiates between shades of the same color can more quickly identify the difference are misleading. The results are so negligible that you really can’t confidently claim it’s inherently true.

Sapir and Whorf did not come up with a reliable theory. Modern linguists know this.

Oliver Sacks wrote about a patient of his who was a painter and lost his sight at the age of 60 after a head injury. When his vision slowly started to return, he lost the capacity to interpret colors. He could only register shades of light (dark and light) and Sacks described it as partial amnesia since he knew what the color blue was but had no idea that bananas were not blue.

His book is called ‘An Anthropologist on Mars’ and I highly recommend it to anyone interested.

This isn't exactly true when it comes to the Bible. The Bible mentions a stone translated as "sapphire" in some translations but is most correctly translated as "lapis lazuli." This comes from "lapis" (stone) and "lazuli" is derived from Latin via Arabic and is used for both "sky" and "blue." In fact, the word "lazuli" is the source word for which several languages use for blue (e.g., "azul" in Spanish and Portuguese, azraq in Arabic, etc.). So, essentially, the term "blue" does appear in both the Old and New Testaments of the Bible -- just as a term derivative of the word "sky" (i.e., "lazuli").  In fact, the Hebrew word for "sapphire" is "sappir" -- which some scholars feel is both a stone (i.e., "lapis lazuli") and, as an adjective, a color (i.e., blue).

All interesting, but there is a crucial mistake made in this video. Languages (more specifically, their color term systems) are here treated (especially at the beginning) as nomenclatures for readily and universally distinguished categories (such as color categories). That is not the case. Languages do not develop terms for this and that color; rather, languages create categories (which vary from culture to culture) in the color spectrum. Cheers.

The sky appears blue due to a phenomenon called Rayleigh scattering.
Even if you stay indoors, you can still see this phenomenon. Shine a red laser at the far wall. With the lights on, you will see NO beam, but you will see a Red Spot on the wall. Now, do this again with a BLUE laser. Not only will you see a Blue Spot on the wall, but you will also see a Blue BEAM. The reason you see the Blue Beam is because the Blue Light is reflecting off of Air Molecules in the room.

I don’t buy the ides that cultures couldn’t distinguish blue from green because of convention. The human retina has specific receptors for blue ( “S type cone cells” ) that are distinct and separate from green ( “M type” cone cells )  so there is no biological reason for them to associate blue with green, as with the  comparison to pink. Blue should inherently be seen distinct from green even if they don’t have a word for it.

What this video refers to as "pink" is actually "magenta". (This is a common mistake.)

In the additive color system, you get pink by adding equal amounts of green light and blue light to red light, diluting the red light and bringing it closer to white. You get magenta by having an equal amount of blue light and red light, with no or little green light present.

In breton the word for green ("gwer") did appear very much later than blue ("glas"). And that "gwer" word actually still cannot qualify naturally green stuff, which are still designated as "glas". If you say "the leaves are 'gwer'" (which we would normally translate as "green"), it'd mean "the leaves have been artificially and chemically painted by mankind in green". However, if you said "the leaves are 'glas'" (which would theoretically mean "the leaves are blue"), it'd mean they're naturally green.
"Glas" can also mean 'gray' as people's hair, or even 'orange/brown' for foxes and random animals.

Soooo yeah. "Blue", always last ? Not that simple. In breton, green appeared afterwards 😇

4- West / white, silver / metal / lung / worry..........
5- Center / yellow / earth / stomach / think ..........

I believe this is in part why we learn the primary colors wrong in School.
Everyone "knows" that the primary colors are Red, Blue and Yellow.

The word for blue in the Tanach (Hebrew Bible) is תחלת (Techeilet), not the modern Hebrew word כחול (Kachol).  Techeilet appears 49 times in the Tanach, and refers to a royal blue dye that was used in the Tabernacle as the Hebrews wandered in the wilderness of Sinai, for the clothing of the High Preist in the Holy Temple in Jerusalem, and for the fringes (tzitzit) of a Tallit (prayer shawl).  It was described as a pure, perfect blue, so magnificent that it was all but impossible to describe.

The issue with the whole "Homer didn't use the word blue" bit is he did (or at least did write things translatable as blue). I know in the translation that I read of the Iliad, one of the sets of ships (I think Odysseus's) in the catalogue of ships was blue, and then the tiles in the home of Alcinous in the Odyssey were blue. There were some other mentions of blue in the Odyssey.
Homer did describe the water in the Iliad as wine-dark, but there is an explanation for it beyond it being that way that doesn't rely on the sea not being perceived as blue, and it sort of is supported by the rest of the Iliad and also sort of the Odyssey. Homer was using color for expressive purposes. The Iliad has a lot of reds, browns, and bronzes, and it generally makes it feel bloody and dusty. The Odyssey uses blues, greens, the mentioned purple sheep, and only gets reds in the end, making it seem extra vibrant and fantastical. You get the same sort of thing with color grading in film.

It might also be worth pointing out that to modern Western-type people who are used to a life mostly spent indoors with artificial lighting and temperature control, the way we think about the ocean/lakes/etc and the sky is very heavily based on the pictures we see of them. If you have even a basic familiarity with the sky and you think about it for a little, the sky is actually not blue most of the time, and even when it is perfectly cloudlessly blue, at the bluest middlest part of the day, that blue is not the same blue everywhere: towards the horizons it becomes more white (even without clouds) and towards the Sun it becomes more yellow/white as the Sun's brightness washes things out. The sea is even worse in this regard. It is actively different colors all over the world, and even those local colors vary strongly due to weather, water currents, viewing angle, etc. We see bodies of water as blue because we have been told that that is the color they are supposed to be, so when we see one that isn't we just assume that something is interfering with that water looking properly blue. Similarly with the sky: when the sky doesn't look blue, we write it off as special circumstances. Ancient cultures didn't do that. The sea and the sky and lakes and rivers were what they were, constantly changing natural phenomena, so there was no reason for them to pretend those things were just failing to be properly blue enough, enough of the time. And if you don't need the sky to be blue or bodies of water to be blue, then you've lost a lot of motivation to bother having a separate word the covers both "that color that part of the sky is, sometimes, where the clouds aren't, where the horizon isn't, and not too close to the Sun or to sunrise or sunset" and also "that quite different color that - maybe - some bodies of water sometimes look like."

Good lord, there are some leaps of logic here that could clear the Grand Canyon. There's an assumption running through this whole subject that these ancient people's written language and spoken are the same, the way English is for us, but that wasn't the case. Anyone who's taken Latin as well as being versed in ancient Roman history can tell you that the classical high Latin that you'd find in Virgil or Juvenal is not what you would hear if you were to walk through the streets of Rome at the time. Every Latin courses I've heard of almost always start out with Julius Caesar's commentaries on the Gallic Wars, because he purposely wrote them in the spoken vernacular as opposed to the typical Latin used in literature, and so it's not as daunting as the literary Latin.
I think the fact that blue doesn't appear often in nature would result in it not being thought of as much either. The Ocean is blue, but not everywhere. The northern Atlantic in New England has always been green whenever I looked out at. Blue was popular with royalty specifically because it was so difficult to produce. Lapis lazuli was the blue you would find during antiquity and the medieval era, and it was insanely expensive to produce.
This video isn't way off the mark, but it's relying on some shaky premises.

So I think the operative concept here is the Voronoi diagram. The implications for racism and gender studies are obviously really important, and other examples are common (exactly which sharp things are “knife” in your language(s)?), but honestly the fact that mathematics has opted to work with extensional sets while brains work with prototypes and exceptions causes a great deal of confusion when people try to talk “precisely” and end up mutating the conversation.

There are even more conceptually striking examples of the phenomenon, by the way, like bipartite “objects”—pen with cap, oldschool phone with receiver, pair of shoes, married couple. These are “things” for which there is little empirical evidence at all, and which we'd be hard pressed to explain to aliens as other than a linguistic exception coupled with a cultural convention. The same thing is going on cognitively (mutually reinforcing mental categories and linguistic tokens), but the space in which the regions are being drawn is itself abstract (unlike the human perceptual colour space, which—although much more structured an interesting than they teach you in either art class or physics—is reasonably empirical and fairly well understood).

Is it that surprising? How many times have you heard a new word that categorized something you hadn't thought to categorize before, and you started seeing the expression of that word everywhere?
In 1990, hungry people weren't hangry. I mean that in a literal sense. They would have been irritable, short tempered, touchy, pissed, or some other word that is not attached to the reason they are expressing those behaviors.
The word "hangry" has a real world effect on how we see and experience irritation in others. Even if you don't know the word, the idea of "I'm impatient, so I need a snack" is part of the culture now.

In essence, even people who were irritable because of hunger were not irritable because of hunger until the idea was popularized.
You could even say "Historians in the year 2500 looked through historical documents from the 3rd century until the 21st century and they discovered there is no mention of hunger based anger in any writings we know of. This video is taking facts to misconstrue them. A better video would be how the Ancient Egyptians invented blue. Regardless of where the word does or doesn't show up an ancient society invented it during ancient times. Why were they the only ones to see use or identify the color.
Below are facts
There’s a long list of things we can thank the ancient Egyptians for inventing, and one of them is the color blue. Considered to be the first ever synthetically produced color pigment, Egyptian blue (also known as cuprorivaite) was created around 2,200 B.C. It was made from ground limestone mixed with sand and a copper-containing mineral, such as azurite or malachite, which was then heated between 1470 and 1650°F. The result was an opaque blue glass which then had to be crushed and combined with thickening agents such as egg whites to create a long-lasting paint or glaze.
The Egyptians held the hue in very high regard and used it to paint ceramics, statues, and even to decorate the tombs of the pharaohs. The color remained popular throughout the Roman Empire and was used until the end of the Greco-Roman period (332 BC–395 AD), when new methods of color production started to evolve.

It's interesting having gone through art school and taken multiple levels of color theory. It kind of rewired the ways I look at color and everything is very objective now, as if the names are arbitrary and my mind keeps track of colors as values--like I can imagine the color picker from photoshop in my mind, which doesn't actually name the colors (a similar thing happened when I was studying web design in high school; I started to think of colors as their RGB color codes and not what their actual names were).  I never see pink as a separate color from red, just a tone or hue (often people consider what is actually a light magenta--or even just magenta--"pink," even though it's actually a separate hue between violet and red and not a tone of red). It's like the difference between phonetics and phonology. That's what he's talking about with the language sounds analogy. Phonetics is the actual sound and phonology is the sound in terms of how we perceive it, with reference to meaning in spoken language.

It's not entirely accurate to say that the word "blue" is absent from Homer and other ancient Greek authors. The most frequent epithet for Athena in both Homeric poems is "γλαυκῶπιςις (-ιδος)" which means both "the one with owl eyes" and "the one with blue eyes".
The word is also used by other authors to describe gemstones in various shades of blue (like topaz) and light-eyed people, but if the eye colour of actual owls is of any indication (aside from the fact that the most important part of the comparison, for these speakers, was brightness and not hue, i.e. the fact that Athena's eyes shone like that of a nocturnal bird in the dark) we have to suppose that their idea for blue extended on the greenish/ yellowish side of the spectrum.
So yes, their way of defining the colour differed from that of an English speaker, in that it was markedly broader and more brightness-related than hue-related, but they definitely had a word for it.

This is why I love language learning. People don't realize that the language you use limits the way you can think about things. A lot of people imagine language learning as just learning the "equivalents" in your target language as your native language, you'll quickly realize though that there are essentially zero equivalents between any language. Someone may tell you that x word means house but what they picture as a house is different, or there may be distinctions between different types of houses and or different words that have more sentimental meanings like "home." Your language actually controls you.

I think it's a defense mechanism developed so that we can clearly distinguish things from other things and stay away from it. So it's our mind helping us survive. People living in the middle of basically a desert country might not have developed this and therefore not be able to clearly see the color blue, but be able to distinguish blue from the greens not because the blue is different, but because the greens are different from that one dot  because green is an important color for them. Different plants and trees might be the difference between life and death and the only way to distinguish them is by a slight color difference. Yes the sea has been around longer than life itself, but since it's always been there, it's not been enough to push our mind to learn a completely new color just because it MAY be dangerous in some cases, rather it's a symbol for life itself and a comfort as well as normal. Now red is important because if you bleed, you need to know that you are in danger, and then green for food when our metabolistic system evolved and so on. Direct quote from the wiki on tekhelet:

“Tekhelet (Hebrew: תְּכֵלֶת‎; alternate spellings include tekheleth, t'chelet, techelet and techeiles) is a "blue-violet",[1] "blue",[2] or "turquoise"[3] dye highly prized by ancient Mediterranean civilizations and mentioned 49 times in the Hebrew Bible/Tanakh. It was used in the clothing of the High Priest, the tapestries in the Tabernacle, and the tzitzit (fringes) affixed to the corners of one's four-cornered garments, including the tallit.”

It’s even mentioned in the third paragraph of the “shema”, the most well known/famous prayer in the Jewish religion. It is quoted from the Bible and used in the daily morning and evening prayers for Jews. So Jews were wearing blue everyday and reciting the word for a specific shade of blue multiple times daily in their prayers, which were as I stated, quoted from the Old Testament.

The distinction of colors has to do more with language than anything. You can damn well see the difference between light green and dark green, but both colors are still "green" in the end (although with modifier words).

Same for people who speak languages without a specific word for "blue": They can damn clearly see the difference between blue and green. One is probably "sky green" and the other "grass green" but both are GREEN in the end because semantics say that GREEN is GREEN.

If people in the future started referring to dark green as "Viridian" and light green as just "green", would they ask why people in the past couldn't see the color viridian??

Hell, if you now learn the difference between crimson, vermilion and scarlet, you can't say that you can see "more colors" than the people who just see "red", because what you did was only adding more semantic categories and not make some profound alteration in your perception... Because you most likely could see the differences in the many colors you refer to as "red", even before you had a name for those different tones.

I don't buy at all the idea that language shapes your perception. It shapes your expression of that perception, but your perception remains the same. Himba people see the same colors as us. Ancient Greeks used to see the same colors as us, and if we told them to make a distinction between blue, crimson or hex 86E407, they would do it without problems.

Anyways, the study of linguistics is underrated.

Similar to how in Finnish, there is the letter s, but no letter z (in the original Finnish alphabet).  Fins have trouble distinguishing between the 's' sound and the 'z' sound in English and pronounce their 's' sound in Finnish anywhere from an 's' to a 'z' sound.  Their ears work just as well as native English speakers, but we easily and readily distinguish between those two sounds while they hear them as pretty much the same sound.  Or how in Polish there is the letter ć and the letter combination cz.  To native English speakers, they both pretty much sound like our 'ch' sound, but to native Polish speakers there's a distinct difference and they're very separate sounds.  Again, ears work just as well, but since their language has a construct that distinguishes between them while ours doesn't, we don't pay attention to the difference and aren't really aware there is one, while they're keenly aware of it.

That is not true. I am greek and I study ancient texts- Homer among them. There were actually words for blue, especially "cyanos (κυανός)" was used a lot. For example, the compounded  words "κυανόπεπλος (the one with dark blue cloak)", "κυανόπρωρος (the ship with a blue prow) are found in Homer' s works. Words associated with "cyanos" are also encountered in plays of Euripedes and Isiodus, but also in texts of Plato. Ancient greeks would also use the word "caleanos (καλλεανός)" , a color named after a bright blue mineral called "calais".

Start with Brent Berlin & Paul Kay's book published in 1969,  and the considerable literature their groundbreaking book generated. It's not that people can't see the colors, it's that they used multiple-word phrases to describe them. You're talking about what Berlin & Kay called basic color terms, which are usually a single word used to describe a focal hue for that color and then a range of various shades of that focal color. Think of English terms for blue:  blue, midnight blue, metallic blue. baby blue, robin egg blue, sky blue, dark blue, light blue, and so on. Every language that's been studied does that, though they do it differently, depending on their linguistic and socio-cultural history. Open the Paint software on your computer and you'll see a grid of warm and cool colors. Go to "custom" and you can make more subtle values, hues, and saturations derived from the basic color. BTW, Russians have to choose WHICH basic color term for blues to use.

The Ancient Greek word for blue was: κυανός

Etymology[edit]
From Ancient Greek κύανος (kúanos), or from Mediaeval Byzantine Greek κυανός (kuanós, adjective), from Ancient Greek κῠᾰνοῦς (kuanoûs)/κῠᾰ́νεος (kuáneos, adjective) from κύανος (kúanos, noun).[1] Cognate with Mycenaean Greek 𐀓𐀷𐀜 (ku-wa-no) and Tsakonian κουβάνε.[2]
Pronunciation[edit]
IPA(key): /ci.aˈnos/
Adjective[edit]
κυανός • (kyanós) m (feminine κυανή, neuter κυανό)
(formal, contemporary) cyan or sky blue
(older): blue
(as noun) the colour cyan

I'm not an expert, just a Greek woman,  but I think because blue is so rare (almost nonexistent in nature as a pigment) they had no special word for it. I mean there are other words in Greek that describe e.g. light blue (γαλάζιος) or (γαλανός) or (κυανός) not necessarily related in the word 'blue' and I'm not so sure that these words are never mentioned nowhere. Maybe, just a guess, they used the words they already had for the colours (or objects..?!) to describe the color of the sky or the sea (which both are not 'standard' blue) or whatever seen as blue in nature. So, as the video made clear, and is not bizarre for me, I strongly believe that human beings of the ancient times in general could see and receive almost the same quality of information regarding nature as human beings of today, they just hadn't invented a strong linguistic mirroring of 'blue', because at that time it wasn't important. Except for some butterflies and flowers, they didn't have to choose between a blue or a red sport shoe or shirt or wallpaper or whatever...! Their most common material were wood, clay, cotton, wool, silk and leather, so obviously there was no need to invent blue. However, Egyptians proved to have a more artistic and vivid imagination for colours, crafting the blue... out of the blue!

It's interesting that when you learn japanese, you learn that some colors have two names, the foreign one that abbreviated from it's english name and the original japanese one, which it's name is a combination of the word "-iro" ( 色) with an object that relates to it . Like pink: you can say "pinku" (ピンク) or the traditional one "momoiro" (桃色) which literally means "peach color". Same goes with Orange; you have "orenji" (オレンジ) and "daidaiiro" (橙色) which means "bitter orange color" (just like in other languages, the name of the color comes from the fruit).
Other colors have also those combined names. Grey is "haiiro" (灰色) which means "ashes color" and brown is "chairo" (茶色) which basically means "tea color." It's kind of fascinating...

πλέων ἐπὶ οἴνοπα πόντον (pleon epi oinopa ponton)

1. There are different words used for colors back then. Especially in poetic language, the colors derive from a natural effect or a shade.
In this case, the color of the sea during a sunset, with a sky full of desert dust, would give you a wine-dark color.

2. Not only it says that 'he sails on a wine-in-look sea', but the sea is also called as a 'pathway', ΄πόντος, which is a popular use for this measure. So now you will also say that the ancient Greeks didn't use the word 'sea' but 'pathway'? Again, this is a poetic language.


In fact, Homer did use Cyaneos that denotes a dark shade of blue potentially merging into black. He describes the sky as big, starry, or of iron or bronze (because of its solid fixity). The tints of a rough sea range from ‘whitish’ (polios) and ‘blue-grey’ (glaukos) to deep blue and almost black (cyaneos, melas). The sea in its calm expanse is said to be ‘pansy-like’ (ioeides), ‘wine-like’ (oinops), or purple (porphyreos).

In addition to these, you get xanthos, erythros, leukos, melas, chloros, ochros...etc

Final part of video: Describes the Baader-Meinhof effect, some variation of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, and my experience with studying trees. Doesn't mention or call attention to the words for either of those two known/hypothesized effects.

Me with trees, though: I used to see forests as "a bunch of leaves on trunks" with occasional maples, weeping willows, or blue spruces (the ones that most stood out from afar). I could tell a few up close -- falsecedar by the bark (though I knew it as "cedar" at the time), madronas as well, and alders by the leaves and general thin trunks -- but mostly it was undifferentiated noise.

But then I spent a year studying the conifers (which are not quite a full overlap with evergreens). And now I can spot tree types from a ways away: the fuzziness of a pine, the wilting-over top of a hemlock. I can categorize a scale-leaf (falsecedar, cypress, juniper) up close, where before I didn't know to make that distinction, and I can notice a few oddities in the wild, some of which have become my favorites even though I can't yet reliably identify them as a specific name (possibly it's larch/tamarack, but I haven't yet confirmed; I know it by the graceful shape and odd needles).

And forests will never be the same.

The Ancient Greek word for dark blue, is Kyaneos (Cyan-os) and for light blue, Glaukos. In Greek mythology, Cyan was a Naiada (lake, river or spring Nymph) from Sicily, the wife of Anapos. An exception to ancient civilizations not using the word “blue” or distinguishing that color, is Japan. The Japanese did not have a word for “green” until the Heian period (794-1185). Everything green was called “blue” (ao). The sky, ocean, & trees were all called blue.

In fact, midori (green) was considered a shade of ao (blue/green) up until post-WWII education made the distinction.
So in this case, blue came before green.

The words Kyaneos & Glaukos could be used to refer to "blue". Just that they included what we'd call other colours in that definition.

The ancient Greeks, as early as 600 BCE were using blues to paint their sculptures and reliefs.  Even cultures from much earlier like Mesopotamians and Egyptians had blue pigments in the form of lapis lazuli from about 4000 BCE and later.  A good example of Mesopotamian art, specifically Assyrian, is The Standard of Ur which is covered in blue lapis.  Not only does this predate the ancient Greeks by about 2000 years, it also isn't too far removed from where the Common Era religions sprung up.  There most likely was a word for blue in most languages of the time, it was just not commonly used because there were very few truly blue things to describe besides the sky.

Well, actually, "κύανος" /ci.aˈnɔs/ (cyanos) was a word in ancient greek used for a steel alloy.
Homer uses it several times in the epic Iliad, to describe the colour of the breastplates of warriors, as well as the blue-like darkness of hair (like Poseidon, Agamemnon and others).
Although not exactly a distinctive word for blue, it has been used to describe a hue of blue, and is the root for the modern-day word "cyan".

There is a treatment of various ways that colours are understood here:

wals.info/feature/134A#2/32.5/151.9
The World Atlas of Language Structures Online
Feature 134A: Green and Blue
by Paul Kay and Luisa Maffi

There is a map where languages are indicated, with these kinds of colour distinction or lack of distinction, as the case may be, with the number of languages in each case:

Green vs blue 30
Green/blue 68
Black/green/blue 15
Black/blue vs. green 2
Yellow/green/blue 2
Yellow/green vs. blue 1
None 2

Also, from Wikipedia: Ao (color)
"Modern Japanese has a separate word for green, midori (緑), although its

It reminds me of many old people categorize, including my own Grandma, here in Greece, who grew up in remote rural places in the mountains during WWII, where schools were shut down. These people had no means of education, or contact with the outer world, so up until they got their first TVs they had NO IDEA what pink is or  even brown. In fact, my grandma used to call brown cats, red. I thought this was strange, so I tested her one day with some crayon colors. She wasn't able to differentiate brown from red and she actually described it as a dark red hue, once I pressured her long enough to see the difference. Now it all makes sense.

So many problems with this video linguistically. He did not do his research. Purple was considered a hue of blue which is what adds to modern confusion.
1) The hebrew bible talkes about blue: תְּכֵ֫לֶת. This word describes blue dyed wool. Very rarely does it describe purple.
2) HOMER and many other ancients use the word ὑακίνθινος which speaks of a hyacinth color (which is a flower normally BLUE but can be purple). They also describe things as sea colored.
3) Sapphires and Lapis stones are both blue and are described in ancient texts from Egypt to India. They also are used as descriptors of other things that are similar colors. The persians name of the sapphire stone literally meant sky colored.

Blue and light blue in Italian are two different colours and are expressed with very different words: blue is "blu", light blue is "azzurro". "Azzurro" is a common word, so it is not a term used for describing a specific shade of blue — as turquoise or cobalt are. For example, the stereotypical "pink for girls" and "blue for boys" in Italian translates with "rosa" and "azzurro", not "blu".

The word-image reinforcement feedback loop described in this video sounds like a new discovery, but it's probably safe to just call it 'learning'. It's likely that, after a short training session, any normal non-colourblind human can learn to make these colour distinctions just as quickly as speakers of these langauges, and non-colourblind visual artists of any linguistic background probably outperform non-artist speakers of all languages - they have more exposure to different shades of colours than most other people.
Another important point is that languages without unique words (lexemes) for specific colours can always just use adjectival forms, compound words, or phrases to describe those colours, which is very common in the world's languages. For example, blue could be 'watery, water-like' (e.g. Persian: ab-i), 'sky green' (e.g. Zulu: okuluhlaza okwesibhakabhaka), 'real blue-green' (e.g. Lakota: tȟo-ȟča), 'oceanic, ocean-like' (e.g. Maori: ao-moana), 'dark' (e.g. Hawaiian: uli, when used to refer to the colour of the ocean), etc. These compounds and substitutions suggest that speakers of other languages are equally good at making these colour distinctions perceptually, and so a great deal more research is required to confirm that there are in fact differences between speakers of different languages.

You got something wrong, and repeated it many times: people whose language don't have a word for a colour (for example "blue") can still tell the difference between blue and any other colour BUT... While the Ancient Greeks didn't have a general colour called "Blue", they did have words which conveyed the colour. For example, the sky (ουρανός) and ocean (ωκεανός) describe the colour blue. The word "cyan" (κυανό) comes from the Greek word for ocean. There is also the word ουράνη which is the Greek word that describes the colour of the sky and is directly derived from it.

So, it's not actually true that the Ancient Greeks didn't have a word for blue - they had many different words for the different hues of blue.

Last, greeks surely knew the dark blue color, as much as they had long terms contacts with Egypt as had also cretans from old age.
