I don't disagree with the part on the brain's pattern matching but I think the universality of the evolution of color terminology is suspicious and likely a result of bias, small sample size, and cherry-picked data.  I also believe the ancient Greeks knew blue as a distinct color since they traded with the Egyptians for it and I doubt they would have prized "just some other shade of green".  The research paper relies on the researcher's map of foreign culture's color terminology into English which is subjective and easily manipulated to produce a desired result.  For instance they outright discard every language's shades of hue, thus arbitrarily labeling a spectrum of colors by one modern Western/English color, and then proceed to draw conclusions based on this manufactured mapping.  They seem to want to support this notion that universally all humans follow a linear progression of development that eventually leads to something like English.  Of course the fact that English is lacking in the degrees of hue that other languages developed naturally is of no consequence since that doesn't support the idea that all humans follow the same linear path of progress.  If "green honey" sounds odd I believe it's not because they saw honey as green but because we fail to understand their color terms as they did in their proper context.

Here is something you didn't pick up on.  Pink is not really light red.  That is, if you add white to say cherry red or blood red or candy apple red, you don't get the pink most people recognize as pink.  You get a lighter shade of that red.  So how do we get the pink most people recognize as pink?  It's simple.  Mix even amounts of red and white then add a tiny smidge of blue.  So pink is really very pale reddish purple, purple being blue and red mixed.

That piece of linguistic news is way exaggerate : it is true that Homer composed his poetry in a very special kind of Greek where names for colors as they exist in modern languages were not available.  Instead he used the words dark (melas : black, blue, dark grey, deep purple), light (leukos : white and all wan or pale colours), lurid (erythros : red, orange, golden yellow), vivid (chloros : light yellow, leafy green, olive brown, yellow ochre) and deep (glaucos : turquoise, light blue, emerald green).  But he also used terms of comparison abundantly, that make perfect sense and are more to the point than modern names.  The colour of the sea he described as that of the darkness of wine : he really meant the colour of wine as it is pressed by feet in a vat, which is dark purplish blue.  The colour of the late afternoon sky he described as deep as a bronze dome : he really meant a dome covered with bronze tiles that are always light warm blue-green and that is exactly the typical colour of the mediterranean sky in summer with much sunlit haze making the colour greener than blue.  Blue pigments were always very popular in Greece since that civilization appeared, it was always the most indispensable colour for all statues, but each shade of them was given a special name following melas, often from a deity.  Blue grapes are still called black in modern French even though they are clearly blue.  As for the Himbas it must be noted that the sky of the African region they inhabit is never blue but golden and grey with dust and humidity on the horizon.  Most Black African cultures perfectly identify blue as the color of indigo but consider it negative like other cultures make black often synonymous with negativity.

They saw blue, but they did not perceive blue in the same way we do. Seeing is a physical and chemical reaction that happens in the eyes. Our eyes technically see (as in detect) colours in the same way unless there is something wrong with the eyes themselves. However, perceiving is something that happens in the brain. It is how the brain analyses the stimulus signal sent by the eyes. We might see similar to others, but we most certainly perceive the things we see differently. To be honest, we aren't even sure if we perceive colours exactly the same as everyone else either since there is no way to measure it.

The colors that show up in a large amount of different objects tend to get their own words, because a single shared characteristic becomes a useful category. If the only blue thing in the world, to a particular group of people, is the sky, they won’t have a word for the color, just words for the sky. In some primitive cultures, the ones that have specific words for blue are those that live among birds, insects, and plants that have blue coloring, and can color objects blue like clothing. If a culture that doesn’t have a word for blue discovers how to make blue paint, they will quickly create a word for that quality because it can now apply to many different objects that are otherwise the same. Blue roofs, for example. It is possible that the Greeks didn’t come up with a word for blue until they came up with a way to make a blue pigment/paint/dye.

As far as we know all conscious beings, be they insects or birds, dogs or humans, perceive colors. (and yes I know dogs see only black and white - still colors, eh?).

But I do agree blue is not a ready color in nature; except if you look up into a clear daytime summer sky. Or can see some way into the ultraviolet, which might account for seeing purple....so many may not be able to define the color with any relevant constructs (words) because it is foreign to their everyday usage and such. But it doesn't mean one doesn't see the color...

Red is so much the first non-BW colour that there are even languages, and not from bacwater or undeveloped places, that use the word for "colour", or a derivative, as a word for "red".
A clear example for people from the US is the state of Colorado, one of the states named in Spanish: the name of the state means morphologically "coloured", but the word was and is still used in Spanish for "red" (in reference to the red soil), particularly when it's bright or is in contrast with black and/or white.

I think they didn't "see" the other colours, the way we do either, they interpreted and described their properties, the brightness, the light or the lack of it, rather than the actual pigment.

The sky was "bronze" because it looked shiny, like a bronze shiny shield. Everything that was fresh and alive was usually described as a yellowish green, from the foliage of the trees, to the blonde hair of a man.

In fact there are at least two adjectives that could describe things which we'd interpret today as "blue", γλαύκος/-η/-ον (glaucos) and κυανός/-ή/-όν (cyanos).

As an artist, I really enjoy trying to "see" through their eyes (although I can't, my brain's not trained for that!!)

Tekhelet (Hebrew: תְּכֵלֶת‎; alternate spellings include tekheleth, t'chelet, techelet and techeiles) is a "blue-violet",[1] "blue",[2] or "turquoise"[3] dye highly prized by ancient Mediterranean civilizations and mentioned 49[4][5] times in the Hebrew Bible/Tanakh. It was used in the clothing of the High Priest, the tapestries in the Tabernacle, and the tzitzit (fringes) affixed to the corners of one's four-cornered garments, including the tallit.[4]

It was not considered as one of the four primary colours key to art, but it was known, named, and used. Kyaneos and glaukos (dark: green, violet or black - like the sea, or light: grey, green or yellow - like the sky) were considered back-drop or highlight colours; indigo = indikon (inky blue) was also known, also cobalt and lapis lazuli as favoured by the Egyptians. The Greeks liked to be finicky about terms, but blue is an elusive hue - being diffuse, it was better labelled according to its nearest light or dark prime colour term; thus it is not so much that they could not 'see' blue, rather they 'registered' it in a different way.
Woad, weld, and madder were popular and well know plant-based dying agents used to colour surfaces or materials. It is well to note that the hue RAF 'Blue' is grey in terms of its light/ dark register, Prussian 'Blue' is black. I hope that helps.

Around 1:27 he says the Bible mentions Black, White, Red, Green, Yellow, but not Blue. First, to me, anything between green and indigo is blue. The sky is sometimes blue. Water is clear, but in certain areas, especially near-tropical, 'where the water is' looks blue (typically light blue). So when the Bible multiple times refers to something as (the color) t'chelet, it's clearly using a word for blue. And when it says something is the color of a sapphire, it's clearly referring to blue. A few sapphires are other colors (basically any actual color except reds), but then there would need to be some explanation "like some rare sapphires" or equivalent.
The linguistics of color is clear that not all cultures divide the rainbow into ROYGBIV - after all, the colors are a continuum. You can divide those 7 colors into 1 color [so translate as "colored" as vs white which is all colors in one, or black which is the absence of any color], or 1 million names. Most English speakers today actually only recognize 6 colors in the rainbow - ROYGBV (leaving Indigo as shades of blue and violet). Fair enough. Some languages use the same word for most of the blue and green part of the spectrum. Did Greek? I wasn't alive back then, so won't try to give my opinion - it would be opinion, not fact.
Saying that the ancient Greeks - or the ancient Hebrews - didn't ever mention the word blue would be valid, since neither was English. Saying they never talked about something that was the color we call blue is just incorrect. The fact that we today don't know when they did is our incomplete knowledge. And yes, our knowledge is more incomplete that many ancient-Greek (classical or koine) or ancient-Hebrew experts are willing to admit.
What is not just my opinion, but actual fact, is that "The Ancient Greeks Could[] See Blue."

Developing adjectives or nouns in a language usually derives from a practical need or a societal desire to specify. And that's cultural before it is linguistic. The French in both France and Québec can't easily rattle off the commonly known names for breeds of dogs as we can in English. In fact, most francophones could barely name more than four breeds. It's not that they don't see and recognize the different breeds, it's that there's not a huge cultural need to know the names. But when it comes to wine or cheese... well, different story. I also question the accuracy of this analysis as the Greeks divided colours by intensity and not by hue but that didn't mean that they literally thought dark blue was actually black or were unable to describe the differences clearly. It's like in Russian, the word for 'brother' and 'cousin' is the same - 'brat' - but they know the difference and will introduce you to a cousin as a 'brother' but specify it as 'his father is my uncle' or something similar.

I study Native American languages, and we had two words for blue in Luhshootseed alone... a word for dark blue, which was also categorized as purple, and a word for light blue, or any blue with no red pigment in it. A counter example that makes the neurolinguistic aspects even more complex: The defining example of a color tends to be the same across languages.

That is, if you present an array of color chips of various shades and hues to someone who speaks a language that doesn't have "blue" as a pure color term (more on that in a moment) but instead has "blue" integrated into "green" and ask them to give the color chip that best exemplifies "green," they will choose the same color that someone who does speak a language with "blue" as a pure color term would choose to define "green." The fact that they don't distinguish "blue" from "green" doesn't alter what they think is the greenest green.

This is a bit connected to the concept of a "pure color term." That is, there are words that are used for color but don't have other meanings. Or at least, to be more precise, any other meanings are secondary to the the use of the term for the color and are derived from the color. For example, "red" means that particular color first and foremost and any use of "red" to refer to something else is deriving that meaning from the use of the color for that concept. But there are other ways of referring to color. This video even gives an example of it while sliding right on by the significance: "Wine-dark." That's a reference to color that isn't a pure color term. "Wine" is primarily a reference to the alcoholic beverage, but it does have a color and if someone talks about "wine" as a color, it carries a meaning (though in this case, the linguistic distinctions of color apply which is why an Ancient Greek might call the sea "wine-dark" but a Modern Englishman probably wouldn't.)

We do this in English. As noted in the video (and again, they just slid right by this without paying attention to the significance), English makes a distinction between certain shades of red with lighter shades being called "pink." It doesn't do this with "blue." Light blue and dark blue are still called "blue." Russian, on the other hand, does make this distinction. Just as English has distinct color terms for light shades of red as distinct from other shades, Russian makes a distinction between light and dark blue (голубой and синий, respectively)

But that doesn't mean English has no words to describe light shades of blue. Instead of a "pure color term," English uses modifiers or other objects with the particular shade to refer to those colors: "sky" blue, "baby" blue, "light" blue, "turquoise," "aquamarine."

This means that "orange" is not a pure color term in English because it is named after the fruit that has that color. And speaking of orange, "brown" is a pure color term...for dark orange (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wh4aWZRtTwU).

So yes, the Greeks described blue objects all the time. Speaking of Homer, the goddess Athena is routinely described as being blue-eyed. He just didn't use the word "blue" and in most translations, she is called "grey-eyed Athena"...even though Ancient Greek doesn't have a pure color term for "grey," either. The specific word used is "γλαυκῶπις," which more directly translates as "gleaming-eyed," but is commonly understood to mean that she has blue eyes.

...so anyway, when i was an adult, i started getting interested in asian languages and culture. and that is when i discovered this:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue%E2%80%93green_distinction_in_language

here's some quotes from the Korean and Japanese part of the wiki article:

" These adjectives 푸르다 are used for blue as in 푸른 하늘 (pureu-n haneul, blue sky), or for green as in 푸른 숲 (pureu-n sup, green forest). 푸른 (pureu-n) is a noun-modifying form. Another word 파랗다 (para-ta) usually means blue, but sometimes it also means green, as in 파란 불 (para-n bul, green light of a traffic light). There are Sino-Korean expressions that refer to green and blue. 초록/草綠 (chorok adj./n.), 초록색/草綠色 (choroksaek n. or for short, 녹색/綠色 noksaek n.) is used for green."...

"The Japanese word ao (青, n., aoi (青い, adj.)), the same kanji character as the Chinese qīng, can refer to either blue or green depending on the situation. Modern Japanese has a word for green (緑, midori), but it is a relatively recent usage.[citation needed] Ancient Japanese did not have this distinction: the word midori came into use only in the Heian period, and at that time (and for a long time thereafter) midori was still considered a shade of ao.[citation needed] Educational materials distinguishing green and blue came into use only after World War II;[22] thus, even though most Japanese consider them to be green, the word ao is still used to describe certain vegetables, apples, and vegetation. Ao is also the word used to refer to the color on a traffic light that signals one to "go"."

i have recently taken an interest in color science, and of the things I've become fascinated with is how much more color exists out there other than the ones were familiar with, and they aren't necessarily shades of the base or primary colors, but depending on the person thats debatable. For instance you can say teal blue, and know that its a shade color, not a primary, or forest green; a shade, but what about chartreuse? what about fuchsia? what about magenta? or can anyone tell me or imagine the difference between purple and violet and indigo? those can arguably all be a primary color too but it all depends if yr referring to the color of LIGHT, or if to the color of PIGMENT, 2 totally different color schemes and conceptions, and even properties, for instance the color of light says that white is the combination of all color, while black is all absence, whereas the color of pigment says that white is the absence of all color, and black is the combo of them all. I'm digressing again but....

Or turquoise, is that a shade a blue or green? its down the middle of 2 primaries(btw unfamiliar with what i mean look up a color wheel, or better look up a Munsell color graph; simply genius graphics charting of color), technically a 2ndary, but unlike forest green or teal blue, which are tertiary colors aka down the middle of a primary and 2ndary

that all actually makes perfect sense to me, its why language is so apart of every culture, as in language was more than just a tool used to communicate, but its been around long enough to have evolution play its role in it, we have actually evolved language. Unlike tools, making fire clothing ext. which all came later, its why we have to be taught those things, but language, now that we've evolved that ability, is one of the first things a baby will stride to learn.

They first learn to walk thus in the beginning, thats what we evolved into; walking man, then they learn to talk (which means we evolved speech after evolving walking on 2 feet), and its at no other time in our lives that learning a language is as easy as it is when you are a toddler, and its actually the most optimal time to teach your child multiple languages.

At no other time after that will it be as easy to learn, and thats due to the fact that it has become an evolutionary trait, thus its only natural that our language has become so closely tied to our conceptions of everything from the physical to the abstract, but especially the abstract, since the abstract has no physical representation of itself, other than the word used to describe itself. we can say an object is red, or a person is brown , but we wouldn't say that thing is a red, or that person is called a brown, thus since the abstract such as color has no physical representation of itself, the word we used to describe them becomes them itself, there is no other way of describing red other than saying that its red, we would never say that red looks like a chair, therefore the only way we can convey the conception of an abstract idea such as a color is to denote words as there representations, thus the words we use for that idea becomes the very foundation of that idea, in other words(no pun intended) the word reinforces the idea, and the idea reinforces the word, as he stated in the video.

Other ways this understanding can be looked at is how brand words have become synonymous with certain products as in being the product itself, a perfect example of this is Kleenex. Everyone knows exactly what it is that I'm talking about when i say Kleenex, most don't even know that Kleenex is merely the brand name of a particular kind of that product, the actual word for that product is called facial tissue, but because we've always said Kleenex, thus, as he said, its a feedback reinforcement loop, to the point that Kleenex has become the de facto word for that product, to the point where many wouldn't even know what you'd mean if you asked for facial tissue

the idea of conveying information thru words as being representations of everyday objects has allowed abstract thought to be represented in ways that could never be done than say if trying to communicate to an unknown people via body language or hand signals(i digress, the only other thing we've evolved before speech is emotion, and its why we can communicate or convey the emotions we are feeling to someone else via body language and without ever having to say a single word)

In the KJV Bible, the word 'blue' occurs fifty times, all of which are in the Old Testament. The Hebrew word translated as this color is tekeleth (Strong's Concordance #H8504), which is a reference to the animal from which the dye is obtained. Its meaning in Scripture is that of representing God (Exodus 24:10, 25:3, 38:18, Numbers 4:6 - 12, 2Chronicles 2:7, Ezekiel 1:26, etc.), royalty (Esther 1:6, Ezekiel 23:6, Jeremiah 10:9), riches (Ezekiel 27:7, 24) or service to God and godly living (Exodus 28:6, 8, 13, 31, Numbers 15:38 - 40, Esther 8:15).

In the Greek language the words have an interpretation, they are not just sounds like in English.
And the names of the colors come from fruits, flowers, rocks and other elements of nature.
In ancient Greek blue was called κυανούν (kyanun from the name of ocean. (Ωκεανός-Okeanos)
Some more examples from modern Greek: K;astani (brown) from Chestnut , prasino (green) from leek, kokkino from the grains (kokkos)of prinos from which they made the pigment. Kitrino (yellow) from citrus, thalassi (thalassa) light blue from the sea, lachani (lachano) light green from cabbage, triantafylli (triantafyllo) from the rose, keramydi (redbrownish)from the tile, zachari (broken white) from the sugar and dozens more shades from various elements. Greek is not only a very rich language, is also a very accurate one.

Back in the days of the ancients peoples...the sky wasn't blue. Hence..the ocean, which reflects the color of the sky...wasn't blue.
Back in ancient times, for a stretch of some 10,000 yrs or more....the earth was experiencing a lot...A LOT....of volcanic activity. Ash was being pumped in to the sky constantly. So worldwide, the sky had a more dirty tan color on good days or inky black when it was a cloudy day.

We also had a climate that was moving from an ice age in to a warm period so you had a lot of new draught cycles which created a lot of dust storms. Hence...more dirty skies.

If we believe the timeline for humanity's evolution, when the Skys were blue 20,000 to 30,000+ years ago..people didn't have an advanced vocabulary or writing. We had basic "words" to match our basic lives. No one really cared about the color of the sky...just the colors of what was flying around in it so they could know if they were the hunter or the hunted. And looked for storms to avoid being rained on or hit by lightning.

As we got more advanced... and softer...our vocabularies expanded and we made words for more things.

He said, "I really love the orange flowers."
I said, "uhhhh...none of these flowers are orange."

Pink is actually a tint of red.
For this explanation, black, gray, and white are the neutrals, and red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and purple are the hues.
(Brown is all colors mixed together.)

So, it goes like this:
Hue + white = tint.
Hue + grey = tone.
Hue + black = shade.

Also, "Fifty Shades Of Gray" is an inaccurate title. Gray is a shade of white, or a tint of black.
Light blue eyes = eyes like the sky. Medium blue flower = a flower like the sea. Dark blue = the evening sky.

Greek is NOT the measure of all things. Basque has blue and not green. Urdin (blue) actually seems to derive from ur (water). Berde (green) instead derives from Spanish "verde" (green).

AFAIK it's very common a basic conceptual palette of white, black, red and blue: Slavic, Iranic and Native Americans used these to color-code the cardinal points.

Back to Basque: it's apparent that the main color distinction (other than white and black) was between red and blue: because there are many placenames with "gorri" (red) that are actually orange or yellowish and it's known that it was also used to describe the color of animals such as cows, horses and rams (which are seldom true red but can be brown-yellowish). Urdin by contrast probably included all blues and greens and maybe even greys. There are genuinely Basque words also for yellow (hori), grey (uher, also seemingly related to water) and brown (nabar).

In Japanese, the standard color aoi means either blue or green. A blue sky, green traffic light and green apple are all "aoi". They have separate words for green (Midori) and for some kinds of blue (sky blue=sorairo, Dark blue=koniro), but aoi is the usual word. Obviously Japanese can tell the difference easily, but the language doesn't mark it as an important distinction, necessarily.
Interestingly, pink and orange usually use Japanese versions of the English words, so these colors weren't even important enough to distinguish until recently. I also love their native word for grey "nezumiiro" which literally means "mouse-color".

The “Ancient people couldn’t see blue” is one of the many myths that stem from a misunderstanding of what linguists call the “Worphian Hypothesis”. Simply stated, language affects the way we think. That seems reasonable enough, until you start claiming that (false), (false), and ancient Greeks couldn’t see blue (probably false).

The ancient Greeks had kyanos, which was probably a dark bluish purple, and glaucus which was a light greyish greenish blue. Like in any language, these colors covered a range of hues, and like in any language, they do not correspond exactly to the terms in that bastard child of Saxon and Norman that we call English. Probably what happened was that someone translated kyanos as purple, and glaucus as green, noticed there was a missing color, applied the Whorfian Hypothesis without caution, and came up with “The Greeks couldn’t see Blue”. And then the Internet happened, and it became some weird repeated factoid, like how (false).

Some things that are true: different languages divide up what seem like distinct concepts differently. Spanish has a single word that covers both “finger” and “toe”, Vietnamese has a single word that covers both “window” and “door”. For that matter, English has a single word that covers the French words “savoir” and “connaitre”. Any student of another language encounters these with some surprise, that such elementary concepts are conceived differently by other languages.

Different languages distinguish colors differently, and have different “” for them. Interestingly, languages seem to acquire these terms in the same order, and what we call blue is among the last colors to get its own term. Modern Vietnamese is in a similar position to Greek; it has a word xanh, used for a range of colors described in English as either green or blue. To make matters worse, , leading people to such conclusions as: “The Vietnamese word xanh must be qualified to have any meaning.”

Exodus 25:4 mentions blue, and the “color timeline” is a bit misleading. I would say that it's not that EVERY language has blue as the last addition, but rather, IF the language has only five colors instead of six, blue is the color that's left out (in favor of black, white, red, yellow, and green). I've done the color survey (https://www.researchgate.net/publication/278665938_The_World_Color_Survey_Database) among a remote tribe in Indonesia, lugging a set of over 250 glass slides with different color hues across rope bridges and through jungles. It was a circulating survey that should definitely be replaced by a digital equivalent. The conclusion across cultures is that the most simple color taxonomy in a given language is just black and white (although this is extremely rare), and then increasing in linguistic complexity red and the other colors are added in that order.

Homer called the sea wine-dark, because THAT sea at THAT specific moment was darker than normal, so dark in fact it could be associated in its darkness with a very darkly coloured wine. The simple fact is that these ancient civilizations DID see the colour blue, but they never had any reason to associate a name to that colour since it was a useless description when a more practical and useful description was to associate the colour with its most common canvases -- the sky and the sea. Blue WAS the sky and the sea, hence the need for Homer to differentiate specific shades of the sea in terms such as wine-dark (as dark as wine, which is in no way a reference to the COLOUR of the sea, otherwise he would have said DARK RED or BLOOD RED or WINE RED, you know, because they actually HAD words for those associations...)

"Fake news" on this video.  Many cultures conceive of color differently, and it's true that black, white and red are the most universally recognized colors by name.  BUT, Vedic texts definitely have a word for blue: "nila," which is used in reference to Siva, the most ancient of devas, as in "nilakantha," blue-throated.  Blue as a description is applied to Siva in several names, all ancient.  Hanyu ("Chinese") definitely used the word for blue in ancient times: witness the classic books of Ch'an Buddhism "Pi Yen Lu" the Blue Cliff Record.  Japanese has an ancient word for blue -"aoi" but not green ("midori" for melon is used).  Many cultures name colors they don't already have a word for by using an object of that color, like English uses "orange."

Yeah, I've seen these claims floating around the Internet before. As I recall, the Himba study was discredited and that's the only study you cited which confirms the central theory of the video. All of the examples usually given are linguistic, such as calling water black - something the Himba study is usually paired with. The sea isn't blue - not most of the time. Water, especially river water, isn't blue either. Rivers tend to be brown or otherwise dark. The only conclusion you can draw from people lacking a word for the colour "blue" is that they didn't have a word for the colour blue, or a use for describing it. Drawing any further conclusion - that people couldn't see it or describe it or differentiate it - is speculation at best.

A somewhat recent Technology Connections video ran into a similar problem talking about the colour brown, and how it's a weird colour. You can't have bright brown, because it starts to look orange - because it is orange. A very dark, usually desaturated orange. Many languages have a word for it because it's common and many people see the colour only within the context of that word so they have trouble perceiving it as the dark reddish yellow that it is, but that doesn't mean that people "can't see" dark orange.

I'm not a native English speaker. You know what colour my language doesn't have a word for? Ultramarine. And yet, when I first saw 16-colour graphics back in the late 80s, I was fully capable of recognising that colour as distinct from the others. I just called it blue - and do to this day. To many people, the word "blue" tends to mean something closer to cyan, usually referred to as "sky blue" despite it not being at all. Or there's my favourite thought experiment. Grab your favourite image editor, grab a dead-centre yellow hue with maximum saturation, then crank the luminance down to 20-30%. The colour begins to "appear" green-ish, even though it's still just as yellow.

Having a word for a thing is proportionate to how important describing that thing is, not in the slightest how well people are able to actually perceive it.

The Hebrew Bible is full of the word “Techelet” which was supposedly either sky blue, turquoise or some kind of purple. It was used to dye wool for the high priest’s garments in the temple & for the tabernacle’s tapestry-like-walls. It was also a commandment for all Jewish men to tie 3 white woolen threads to each corner of any 4 cornered garments along with one of the threads in each corner also being techelet. The strings were to serve as a constant reminder to follow the Torah’s hundreds of commandments & to keep away from sinning throughout the day. The blue color was seen as a reminder of the blue sea, which then led one to think of the blue sky, & then led one to think of Gd on his heavenly throne.
It was also used for royalty & is sometimes translated as royal blue. This dye was derived from a certain type of rare snail that would sometimes wash up on the beaches of the Mediterranean. The Romans prized this expensive & rare dye so much that they eventually outlawed its use for anybody who was not royalty. So the Jews had to stop wearing it. After the Roman ban had been lifted, the detailed Mosaic tradition of which exact species of snail could qualify for fulfilling the biblical commandment had fallen out of use for so long that over time the knowledge got lost. Nowadays, scientific inquiries & research has claimed to identify the correct critter but most Jews are unwilling to reinstate something that was lost without a reliable unbroken tradition while a minority decided they have nothing to lose & started using the dye again. The point is that the Techelet was described in ancient sources & compared to the color of the sea & sky so I don’t know what this guy means when he says that there is no mention of the color blue in the Bible. It’s true that the modern Hebrew for blue is not in there because that’s a 130 year old invention but the ancient relative is used all over.

Pretty much bullpucky. There are 49 references to the color blue (תְּכֵלֶת, tᵉkêleth) in the Old Testament.

"Important evidence persuasively suggest that Biblical tekhelet was in fact sky-blue. Assyriologist Wayne Horowitz explains that the Sumerian word uqnu, the word for the gem lapis lazuli, was used for the color blue and its shades. The term was applied to the sky and to blue wool (uqnatu). When the foreign word takiltu, Hebrew tekhelet, was adopted into Akkadian, the same cuneiform signs as uqnatu were used. To the ancient Mesopotamians, therefore, the color of lapis lazuli and the sky were equivalent to the color of tekhelet." https://www.biblicalarchaeology.org/daily/ancient-cultures/what-color-was-tekhelet/

Ancient artists often had to limit their use of blue because appropriate pigments (such as lapis lazuli) were expensive and hard to come by, so of course it doesn't show up in paleolithic cave paintings. The earliest known blue dyes were made from plants – woad in Europe, indigo in Asia and Africa, while blue pigments were made from minerals, usually either lapis lazuli or azurite. Blue became more popular in ancient art once the Mesopotamians and Egyptians discovered how to make blue glaze and pigment from copper and cobalt.

Most ancient languages of maritime cultures have a word for the color of the sea, but the actual color may vary considerably between blue, green, gray, clear and reflective (shiny) depending on the clarity and color of the nearby waters. Proto-Germanic had a word for blue (*blæwaz) that got transmitted to all its daughter languages with the meaning blue. It was derived from Proto-Indo-European *bhle-was that apparently described the shining sea on a bright sunny day.

Ancient Greeks distinguished dark blue, kyaneos (Κυάναος); light blue, glaukos (γλαύκος); and the color of indigo dye, indiko (ινδικό).

"Not only is our perception of the world an illusion, our brains are an active part of creating it."
This should be unpackaged. What does "active part of creating it" refer to? Our perception or the world?
Our brains do enable us to perceive, but neither our brains nor does our perception create the world. So, are brains can "create" perception, but they create the ability to perceive, along with our sense organs. Brains cannot create the world. For one thing, there is an improper separation of our brains and the world. Our brains are part of the world, they exist in the world. Something must exist before it can be perceived. The neuroscience studies must be unpackaged as well. The Himba people can tell the difference between the different greens because they have trained themselves to spot the differences between the greens. When neuroscientists analyze such information, the "highlighting" our brains do does not point to some feedback loop that is supposedly making different colors amplified. The "highlighting" is a lighting up of the brain when a certain concept is brought to the surface. So, we could see a similar lighting up of the brain if a cat was shown to us and we recall the concept "cat." And the same would happen across other cultures that have words for the same concept "cat." So, if you ask a Himba for the difference between the colors of the wheel with one blue dot, the reason their brains would not light up when seeing this blue dot is because they do not have a word for that particular color. The brain lights up for the different green dot because they have been specifically trained to identify this differently, whereas the blue one has no specific training. Now with pink a similar process happens. We still see the difference between the various reds, no matter if we have the word "pink" or not. A person knowing the word "pink" will have a lighting up event in their brain, while the person not having this word will not have a lighting up event. So, the person without the word might take a few seconds to think of something that is deeper, like referencing hues, which then the lighting up event would occur.

One of the fundamental problems that people overlook when referencing colors is that they do not properly understand colors and the activity of light. For instance, the Blue Morpho Butterfly. This butterfly is said to not be truly blue because it is a reflection between different branches of a Christmas tree-like pattern on its surface. The light bounces in between these branches and most of the light continues down the triangle shape between the branches while the blue light reflects back outwards, thus we see blue. One problem with calling this as not true blue is that people are not looking at how light is fundamentally absorbed or reflected. Whether from a flat surface or a Christmas tree-like surface, it is electrons that reflect light or allow it to continue further into the object. The same sort of reflection is happening on both the butterfly's surface and the surface of a blue object, its just that the blue surface does the action of reflection on a much smaller scale. It is not the action of reflection on the surface or the action of processing light on the surface that says something is true blue or not. It requires two things. The perceived thing (photons) and the perceiver, but the objectivity of this analysis lies in the perceived thing itself, the photons. Since they travel with their wavelength in the blue range, they are therefore blue. Of course the phenomenon of the blue color can't exist until a perceiver perceives it, but this is not a creation of the world or the proof of subjectivity. The phenomenon of blue in our brains is rooted in the objective (objective as in existing apart from human consciousness) existence of the thing and of the photons.

Another popular question that tries to root out the objective or subjective nature of conscious is this "If a tree falls in the middle of the woods and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?" The sound has two aspects that people tend not to identify. They think of the sound as existing or not existing, but then run into confusion. Many rightly see that if one chooses either answer of no sound or yes sound, that something is off about this answer. Sound engineers and physicists that work with sound do not help with this question. Sound engineers and physicists think that the sound is the movement of the air around the falling tree, so they say yes, the falling tree with no one around makes a sound. Others believing that the sound only exists in the brain, say that no, a sound is not made, and make rationalizations to keep from taking note of the movement of air. Both are partially correct and both are partially wrong. The basis of the sound still exists, no matter what. The phenomenon of the sound requires a perceiver for the sound to manifest, but it also requires the movement of air against the ear. Therefore, one aspect of the sound exists in the middle of the forest with no one around, but it cannot be heard.

In most discussions like these a false dichotomy is always set up. That there is a mind-body dichotomy or a dichotomy between the world as it is and human consciousness. The world exists, humans exist, humans are part of the world, and thus must be included in the world when we speak of it. Consciousness formed for animals to be able to move about the world and engage with it. The difference sense organs enable us to seek pleasure and sustenance and to avoid pain and death. In these discussions, the long history of the success of life is disregarded and that this supposedly illusory perception we have is just some weird disjointed phenomenon. From the first advents of life to today, you are the latest link in the chain of a long line of successful living. Imagine that for a moment. You are part of a chain that stretches back millions of years or billions of years to today and this is an incontestable fact of a chain of uninterrupted, successful life. And at this certain point in time of this long successful chain, you are existing and surviving and being successful because of the certain type of being you are, namely a human being, that possesses the type of consciousness that humans possess. Human beings are successful because of this type of consciousness. To equate our consciousness with illusion-factories is to make a mockery of human beings, as if we exist causelessly and with no engagement with the world. That we are separate from the world and exist because of some unintelligible process, because of lies or falsehood. Illusions occur because of a failing consciousness or a failing brain. Illusions result from an interference in the processes of a healthy brain. So, to equate regular everyday perception with failing perception is to build into your knowledge a fundamental problem with human consciousness and human life. It is to say that you cannot know anything and that life is unlivable. But remember, there are millennia upon millennia of evidence that proves life is lived and that we are successful living beings.

This presentation is rife with factual and historical errors.  The example of Homer describing the sea as "wine dark" was not because he couldn't see blue, or was unfamiliar with it.  It was because he, and all other Greek bards, often chose to describe things metaphorically as a form of foreshadowing or allusion.  Further, ancient Chinese, Hindu, Norse, Celtic, Babylonian, Native American, and many other contemporary cultures not only had words for "blue," they manipulated the color in the form of paintings, textiles, jewelry etc.  Hell, the ancient Picts literally covered themselves in blue powder for religious ceremonies and sometimes for battle.  Just because a culture doesn't evince a word for "blue" doesn't mean they couldn't see it.  Give me a break.

At 1:17, you said the color blue isn't even mentioned in the Bible, but that's not correct. The color blue is mentioned 50 times in the Hebrew Bible (Tanakh/"Old Testament"). The word is "תכלת" and only means "Blue," as opposed to something like black or green. It's also distinct from purple, which is interesting. The word first appears in Exodus 25:4 and was actually important since the Hebrew priests wore blue specifically (Exodus 28:31); plus, the Hebrews wore something called tzitzits, which have blue in them (Numbers 15:38).

No. And, er… no and no.

Briefly. Of course the Greeks saw blue. Names aid speed in distinguishing hues but there's no evidence of names changing our perception of hues. Translation is the key; even modern English and modern German do no share lexical equivalence in colour names. There are colour descriptors in each language that do not exist in the other. And on translation, the King James Authorised Version in English has 48 occurrences of the word blue regardless of what was used in the original Hebrew, Aramaic and Koine Greek. Also 41 green, 52 red, 4 yellow, 48 purple, 61 white, 18 black and 4 brown. But 0 orange.

For someone who actually knows about this stuff — and supplies scholarly references — try Peter Gainsford: http://kiwihellenist.blogspot.com/2020/05/ancient-greek-colours.html

Although I don't know about other culture, I did some research about ancient Chinese literature. And based on my childhood memory, most of the time, ancient Chinese writers and poet used the word for green, "青", pronounced "qing", to represent both green and blue. However, I also remember seeing description of "Blue", translated to "蓝 / 兰", pronounced "lan", in old poem and literature as kids. One of the many explanation I found, is that the color blue was usually the cloth color used by most average or below average people. For example, I remember the word "蓝衫"， translated "blue shirts", was sometime used to describe the writer is in a poor or below average lifestyle. And if you think about it,  most of the literature and poem got passed down history were usually from wealth, and even royal family in ancient China, it makes sense that the word "blue" didn't show up much. Because it a symbol of poverty.

There's no word for "brown" in Homer either. Red is often used as a substitute, where it doesn't distort the meaning. For example, saying someone has red hair when it's really just brown is ok, but saying a woman has red eyes when they are really brown means something totally different. To get around this, women in Homer are sometimes complimented by calling them "cow-eyed", meaning they have big shiny brown eyes. The colours of things were obviously conveyed by comparison with common objects (as they certainly were by the Romans). The reason "blue" doesnt appear to exist in ancient chinese (and other confusian countries) text is because the word used for it, 青, back then (and still is actually) referred to a range from blue to cyan to certain shades of green. 绿 is what most green shades were referred to with. The modern word for blue, 蓝, didnt come until much later. So in actuality, there was a word for blue, but if you dont know about the history of the language you could make this mistake.

Also, the chinese have been using barium copper silicate as blue dye since at least 1000 bc though believed to be invented long before 1000 bc. The statement that they didnt have access to blue dye is incorrect and it doesnt make sense for them not to have a word for blue.

OK, so my two cents: this video is not right. The ancient Greeks had two words for blue, one for dark blue/navy blue--κυάνεος--and one for light blue/baby blue, close to the hue of eyes some people call "grey"--γλαυκός. Indeed, the English word for Ocean comes from a variant spelling from κυάνεος (kyaneos); you add the definite Greek article "o" to the name and you've got Okyaneos, literally the Blue One. Kappa in Greek was rendered with "c" in Latin and as the "c" in Latin went from sounding like a "k" to more like a "ch" or "s" depending on where in the word it was, you get Ocean. Glaukos, conversely, was Plato's brother, just with an "n" instead of an "s." He was basically called the Baby Blue One. And he kind of was a baby, if you read the Platonic dialogues.

There's a more precise analogy to language: phonemic boundaries. If you smoothly vary the actual audio wave of closely related phonemes, like say L vs R in English, English speakers will perceive a sharp binary transition between the two sounds, not sounds that have more or less L/R character, even though the physical characteristics of the sound would support that interpretation. Meanwhile speakers of some Asian languages have trouble pronouncing English L/R distinctions because they literally do not hear the difference. And they do not hear it because the distinction between those two sounds, which are similar in articulation, does not carry semantic implications in their native language (this is basically the definition of a phoneme).

After seeing a video that basically said that cyan is NOT a shade of blue, but rather its own colour with its own shades, I... literally started seeing cyan everywhere.

And now that I am aware of it, I see it absolutely everywhere. I will now just casually describe something as cyan and not even think twice until my friends say "what the heck is cyan??"

But: "The ancient Greeks classified colours by whether they were light or dark, rather than by their hue. The Greek word for dark blue, kyaneos, could also mean dark green, violet, black or brown. The ancient Greek word for a light blue, glaukos, also could mean light green, grey, or yellow. The Greeks imported indigo dye from India, calling it indikon. They used Egyptian blue in the wall paintings of Knossos, in Crete, (2100 BC). It was not one of the four primary colours for Greek painting described by Pliny the Elder (red, yellow, black, and white), but nonetheless it was used as a background colour behind the friezes on Greek temples and to colour the beards of Greek statues" Copy pasted from Wikipedia - https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue#:~:text=The%20ancient%20Greeks%20classified%20colours,green%2C%20grey%2C%20or%20yellow.

having more difficulty distinguishing a color is not the same thing as not being able to see a color. The Greeks would not have thought the sky was monochromatic just as the English didn't view the naranja (orange) as monochromatic prior to developing the word orange. Before the creation of the word, they still saw orange, they just called it yellow-red, and naranja were called "golden apples." 

At any rate, the Greeks and Egyptians shared knowledge and art frequently, Egypt eventually becoming part of Greece (the Ptolemaic dynasty), and the blue sky and blue water certainly would have been accessible for this Mediterranean culture. Our eyes evolved to see blue because seeing blue was useful for survival, so you will find the ability to see blue, even if you have difficulty precisely identifying it, in all cultures, and at all times, worldwide. Whether or not something receives a distinct word, however, is a bit rarer, since language develops to be useful. If you have no cacti plants in your region of the world, you may never develop a word for cacti. If there are tons and tons of cacti where you live, you might develop a dozen with great nuance and complexity to capture a wide variety of cacti.

While it's true that naming a thing can increase its importance and recognizability, I do think it's important to not overstate the case.

It's kinda the same with direction. An Australian native language has no word for front, back, left or right and they instead use the cardinal directions. This has caused the tribe that spoke that language to developed an innate sense of direction. They wouldn't be able to tell their left from their right, but always know which is their north foot...or west foot or whatever is the case in any given situation.
As that language (the language, not the tribe) is approaching extinction though, that ability is becoming lost along with the language.

Just like in many languages some words have different meanings in a different context and the ancient Greeks had kyanos, which was probably a dark bluish purple, and glaucus which was a light greyish greenish blue, and in different sentences these words meant different more accurate ~colors, shades of blue. Added the fact, that blue pigment was the hardest to make, we can assume that there weren`t the actual blue "etalon" the true blue color until some time, so there was no specific word for it in many cultures and languages..

But even so this is BS theory, because many languages have identical words for nearly completely different things for example Spanish has a single word that covers both “finger” and “toe”, Vietnamese has a single word that covers both “window” and “door”.. So the explanation of this topic that is based on linguistics is really poor and doesn`t provide enough evidence.

In this video, the narrator points out how close "black" is to "blue" in both the visual mind and computer-light-generated color palettes.  The same guy points out that modern words for "blue" tend to be adapted from ancient words for "black."  Then this same idiot makes the whole premise of his video that the ancient Greeks didn't have a word for blue.  Reality is that mis-translation of certain Greek words originally appearing with prefixes, suffixes, and perhaps accent markers is the reason why English translations of Homer have so many references to "black" and none to "blue."  The references to "blue" were certainly there, but weren't recognized as such in the hundreds or thousands of years between the time that language was last spoken on Earth and the English translations were performed.

In fact, when midori came into use it was viewed as a shade of blue.

This video missed out a huge part of how ancient and tribal cultures use colours, I'm actually really surprised this wasn't included.
Unlike how modern societies have words for just the colour on its own, tribal and ancient cultures' "colour words" also describe a host of features associated with that colour, greeness might be used not only to describe something that is green visually, be maybe something that is unripe, or young, or associated with growth, whether or not it's actually green.

So take the famous "wine dark sea" example from Homer, the mistake here would be to assume that he is comparing the colour of the sea to the colour of red wine. Sure the sea can be dark, and wine is as well, but there are other associations as well, such as how dangerous or treacherous it can be, which is something the ancient Greeks heavily associated with un-dialuted wine. (Not to mention that large vats of wine froth in a similar way to the sea - the brewing process being more familiar to the vast majority of ancient people than it is to us).

Not true. Greeks could of course see the color blue. What happens is that, because randomness in the way languages are conceived, they held a word for the color between blue and purple and another one for the one between cyan and green, turquoise or something like that. As happens in english or in spanish, those two simple colors had nuances, and what we think as pure blue was described as being darker or lighter that some of this colors. Is like saying English people do not see the dark green color because they don't have an specific name for it.
More the less, as Latin didn't have equivalent words to those two for the name of the colours, they translated kyanos to purple, which wasn't purple but dark blue-purple and glaucus, which was turquoise, to green. Therefore the error and the false claim of the video.

I studied Japanese for three years, and if I am remembering correctly, the Japanese language developed the word for blue before it developed the word for green. The former is "aoi," and is applied, for example, to the color of the ocean. The latter is "midori." My recollection is that even today this word is not often used in regular speech, but if there is a native speaker out there who knows this is wrong, I invite correction.

If I am right, I'm not saying this contradicts or "disproves" the main thesis of the video, which seems to be basically right. I do quarrel with the idea at the end that our perceptions are an "illusion." Rather, our perceptions are contextualized by the power of reason, but since language is the tool through which reason operates, and since language is a construct affected by culture and many other factors, people of different cultures with different languages will have different ways of communicating what is objectively the same experience, such as seeing the color of the sky, or the sea. But differences are not "Illusions."

It's understandable that the names of colors were created to describe things in nature. Thus, black may have been early on not a color, but the description of the absence of color (which it is) at night. Red would describe the color of blood and some plants. Green would be the color on many plants, and brown, the color of the earth. The color of white is almost completely absent in nature and there's little reason to have had a name for it. The only white things (to us) in nature are clouds, snow, and some flowers. Clouds are usually grey, snow very rarely occurs in the temperate zones where language started and is only seen as white when it accumulates, and white flowers and plants don't occur in enough abundance to require a separate named color.

As far as assigning color to specific things, I once heard a linguist describe a researcher in contact with a remote tribe who was investigating what colors they called various things. After pointing out a number of items and getting responses, he pointed to the blue sky and asked what color it is. The person being questioned had no idea what the researcher meant since he was pointing at the empty sky. There was nothing there and thus there was no color at all.

This is all complete bullshit. How we see, and how we categorize colors are completely different. Even if a society has no word for blue, doesn't mean they perceive it any differently. What they DO categorize are different attributes. So why the Himba people have "trouble" with is not the difference in "blue" but where to order that blue.
If given a blue object and a bunch of green objects. The Himba person could easily tell you which one is completely different than the rest, if you carefully explained WHAT "difference" you wanted.
This is an extreme example of the Sapir-Whor hypothesis.
As for Homer. His works were poetry, not prose. The greeks also paid more attention to the VALUE of the color, rather than the HUE. So a bronze sky would mean the intensity of VALUE, rather than the HUE of blue. Or the dark wine VALUE of the ocean.

The words blue, purple and crimson are used tens of times in the Torah. Blue was a common and prominent colour used in the Holy Tabernacle in the desert, later in Shiloh, and later in the Holy Temple in Jerusalem.
If you go to the Temple Museum in Jerusalem you will see actual archaeological evidence of items used in the Holy Tempe which were blue and are referred to as blue in the Torah!

Exodus 38:1 And out of the Blue (Hebrew: Techelet), Purple (Hebrew: Argaman), and crimson wool they made the meshwork garments to serve in the Holy, and they made Aaron's holy garments, as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Exodus 38:2 And he made the ephod of gold (Hebrew: Zahav), blue (Hebrew: Techelet), purple (Hebrew: Argaman), and crimson wool, and twisted fine linen.

Chapter 38 goes on to use the word Blue 10 times and Crimson seven times.
Chapter 26 uses the word Blue four times and Crimson three times.
Chapter 28 uses blue 8 times and crimson five times.
Chapter 35 uses blue four times. The commandment was given for good hearted women to dye and spin garments of blue (Hebrew: Techelet. mentioned first), purple (Hebrew: Argaman) and Crimson (Hebrew: Toladat) for wool and linen garments.

Chapter 36 uses blue four times. Blue curtains were used in the Holy of Holies. Blue coloured poles etc.
See here for a picture of the Holy of Holies with blue featuring prominently as a colour:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_of_Holies

Chapter 4 used the word Blue four times.

Book 24 - one mention towards the end (blue-eyed)

for 8 total references.

Is it true that the ancient Greeks did not have name for color blue?

No. They had several words for blue.

γλαυκός (glaukós) means “light blue”, or maybe “greyish blue”.
κύανος (kýanos) means “blue”.
κυάνεος (kyáneos) means “dark blue”.
πορφύρεος (porphýreos) means “purple” or “purplish blue”.
The idea that the Greeks had no word for blue comes from Homer’s description of the sea as οἶνοψ (oinops), which literally means “wine-faced”, but is normally translated into English as “wine dark”.

I am permanently confused as to why people take this as evidence that the Greeks had no word for blue. The potential meanings here are multitude- the sea at sunset does look like wine. Right out in deep water, the water does take on an almost purple colour; he could be describing that. The sea at night very often looks purple, if it doesn’t look outright black. He could be describing a particular quality of the light and the way the sea reflects it. He could be speaking poetically, and claiming that the sight of the sea is intoxicating.

How people have arrived at the conclusion that the likeliest explanation is that the Ancient Greeks had no word for “blue” is utterly beyond me.

Gilgamesh doesn't say "blue," but does mention Lapis Lazuli, which suggests that they saw blue and even had a name for one hue, which is still the pigment preferred by artists for deep, non-fugitive blues. Expensive, though. And while some archeologists in the 19th century wondered if the ancient Hellenes could even see blue, blue has since been found in some grave paintings showing that the archaic Greeks, at least, appreciated the colour. "Wine-dark sea" is an interesting adjective too, as some red wines turn blue when they are well diluted with water.

Of course Greeks and other cultures could see blue, there are countless artifacts around the ancient world painted blue. There are misconstrued translations of Greek to English on color names that have led to this. Kyanos and Gaucos for example cover the full spectrum of blue-blue green-grey depending on what you are talking about, in addition they use the descriptive terms. Anyone who has been on the water at nightfall knows the seas looks wine-dark, as though a vast ocean of wine. If one is looking for one word that is "Blue" covering all shades of blue then you won't find it for the reason that the descriptions and the words covering the spectrum of hues is all that was needed to get the meaning of what one was talking about. And most cultures prob operated the same way, is only in our modern recent times that we need a word or categorization for every color variation. Because there was no word "Blue" doesn't mean people couldn't see the color until recently as some ridiculous articles online are claiming.

The assertion that the Bible lacks a word for blue is wrong.  Its most ancient passages repeatedly use the word “tekhelet,” which means “blue” and also what we would call turquoise (and possibly is cognate with it).  For example, here is the more recent Biblical passage in Jeremiah 2:10 for “blue and crimson”:  תְּכֵלֶת וְאַרְגָּמָן.    Tekhelet was described in the Talmud as the color of the sky but today we’d find it most often in clothes dyed denim.  Now modern Hebrew also has a color name for a darker blue, kachol, but the statement in the video as to Biblical Hebrew is wrong.

You mean indoeuropean and possibly finnish.

The steppe languages around turkic and mongolian where hungarian got blue from, all use the proto turkic "kök" root for blue, which was analogous to 'sky'. Turkish further uses it both as a word for blue and green.
Now unless you want to argue that to the people of the endless plains the sky seemed green, then that language group had in fact a word for blue from which the word for green developed.

And specifically in hungarian, it being a more rough and tumble language picking up things left and right, the current word for blue was used closer to the migratory origin, whereas the current word for green is proto-indo-european in origin, with whom hungarians only had contact later.
So in this case it is also entirely possible that the current word for blue is more ancient than the current word for green.

The Photoshop colors thing - well, very, very dark red is also close to black. Still, I see why people thought of blue as blackish.

What's important biologically is whether we see colors the same way as ancient Greeks, and of course we do. Organisms from 30 million years ago were very different from modern humans, so that point is off.

Ok I couldn’t resist and I have to admit, there were some Interesting tidbits to be salvaged from the clickbait. The feedback loop galvanizing our vision of the world around us through language alone is quite interesting, as is the thought that only when we start actually seeing objects as an artifact of our fascination other than our superstition, we look for more precise words to describe them. And with colors I thought was the most convincing argument that naming them came on the back of our ability to recreate them (blue is indeed often a hue, or light fraction instead of a pigment, like with the butterfly) We will look for a word to specify the color once we have found a way to recreate them. And blue has been famously difficult to recreate as a real and pure pigment. Maybe that is why blue was mostly a royal color (blue blood), for that exact reason: rare, expensive and therefore it required the luxury of enough time and resources to develop the intellectual and emotional ability to enjoy it for what it is. A peasant couldn’t care less if the pillow he rested his weary head on was grey yellow or pink. Survival mode we already know for decades limits the intellectual development of our brains and makes us literally dumber (it lowers our IQ).

Pink is not a shade of red. Something that is truly pink if you look at the RGB values has slightly more blue in it than green, if there are equal amounts of blue and green it's not pink it's light red.

The hexadecimal code for pink is FFC0CB, FF for the Red value which in base 10 is 255, C0 for Green which has a base 10 value of 192, and C8 for Blue which in base 10 is 200; more blue than green.

It's not a, "lighter hue," it should be, "lighter value." Hue applies to the color itself, what position it is on a color wheel, hue is between 0° and 360°, both 0° and 360° are Red, 30° is Orange, 60° is Yellow, 120° is Green, 240° is Blue, 275° is Indigo, 300° is Violet; or as they teach in art classes to remember those colors easier Roy G. Biv - Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, and Violet.

Pink has it's own hue. As I mentioned Red is 0° and 360°, Pink's hue is 350°, it's primarily Red with a lot of Green and Blue mixed in, but more Blue than Green.

When you're talking about the brightness or darkness of a color that's the color's value not it's hue, the hue is the color itself.

Colors are define by Hue, which I already covered; Saturation which determines how close the color is to being a shade of Black, Grey, or White (0 Saturation would be grey scale, 100 would be the pure color, and anything in between would determine how faded or washed out the color looks); Brightness / Value determines how bright or dark the color is.

All of that being said I did enjoy your video, as an artist I just had to correct your color terminology.

Even if they didn't have a word for it though, the ancient Greeks very much used the colour blue and we're aware of it - the temples we see in plain sand stone colours these days used to be coated in white stucco - and this white stucco was accented with striking colours, the most common for Greek temples being blue and red.
Imagine, for example, the sculpted head of a lion serving as a water spout on the eaves of the roof - these lion heads were very common on temples, and while their faces usually remained the plain white of the stucco, their manes were typically painted an eye-catching and imposing shade of blue.

Not to mention that the Greeks and the Egyptians existed in very close cultural contact - most of the things we consider "Greek culture", they learned from the Egyptians first.
There was flourishing trade between the two nations, too.
So there would've definitely been awareness of the Egyptian colour definition for blue too, even if the Greeks didn't end up borrowing the word for their own language.

It seems someone only just discovered Sapir and Whorf hypothesis, otherwise known as linguistic relativity.

Interesting notes; “pink” is “light red” in Danish. In Japan, to this very day, they say that unripe fruits, mountains and stoplights are “blue” and not “green.” In Japanese, linguistically, “green” (緑) came after blue. Of course, the Japanese borrowed many words and characters from the Chinese, so any ideas of color were borrowed from them as well. The evolution of the character for “green” is interesting too, because it’s a reference to the color of copper once it starts rusting. Also, the word qīng (青) in Chinese describes a number of, what we in English would describe as “different colors.” It is supposed to describe the colors of a budding plant, and this can range from yellow, to light green, to deep green, to blue, to black. They began to use 緑 to refer to green and 藍 to refer to blue. In Japan, 青 still refers to “blue,” but it can be used to mean “green” in the literal and figurative sense still. Of course they have adopted 緑, but no one says “the fruit is still 緑,” “the light turned 緑,” “the grass is 緑,” all of this is still “青.” (blue, but actually green) Adding “sun” (日) gives “clear sky” (晴), so obviously they had a concept of what color the sky was supposed to look like on a clear day when the sun can be seen. A British friend of mine tells me that what Americans call “yellow light,” they call “amber.”

If I’m not mistaken, the idea linguistic relativity was abandoned in the 20th century. But hey, it makes for a good video topic.

The theory for how languages affect the way we see the world is called the "Sapir-Whorf hypothesis" for anyone interested in learning more!!

Great video 👍 Lots of truth there, but just wanted to point out that it's not accurate to say the word for "blue" doesn't appear in the Hebrew bible. For example, Numbers 15:38 describes the "blue cord" that was part of the ritual fringes the Jews were commanded to wear. The word "תכלת"/techeleth meaning a shade of blue matching the color of the sky. This is the same term found in ancient Aramaic and Akkadian.

Now, re-evaluate this without assuming that the energy output of the Sun has been constant with the exact same transmission of electromagnetic frequencies (including visible light) for millions of years. Hint: If we orbited a blue star, the color red would be far more difficult to distinguish. A yellow star lacks in blue frequencies, while a red star lacks in both green and blue. If the star is not transmitting a certain color (electro-magnetic frequency) then that color can not be reflected off of objects that ARE that color. In the case of a yellow or red star, a purely blue flower would appear black or dark and the present atmosphere would appear gray or dark.
Hint 2: A star's color is mostly determined by it's mass (not necessarily size) and temperature and what fuel it is using for fusion at the time. All these parameters change over time changing the color of the star. Occasionally, sometimes due to external events, these parameters can change abruptly. An abrupt change in the Sun's temperature and energy output could cause temporary widespread chaos with Earth's weather patterns. I find it strange that we're talking about the semantics of the word "blue". I mean, the Greeks had blue. They used azurite, which they called frit, and lapis, as well as Egyptian blue. I'm sure they had terms for those materials, which would clearly have referred to the concept of blue. I have no argument that linguistics can affect perceptions, including that of color, but ancient Greek art demonstrates clearly that they absolutely had a perception of at least several distinctive shades of blue, and used them enthusiastically. The entire argument offered in this video reminds me of the circular "Clovis First" argument that was virtually anthropological LAW until very recently. The argument being, essentially, "We have no evidence of anything older than Clovis." "But what about this evidence?" "It must be false... we know nothing is older than Clovis, because we have no evidence of anything older." Of course, in this case, it's linguistic. Cool story, bro. Next time, ask an artist about color, instead of a philosopher.

This explains my relationship with the gray-scale. I learnt there was Black, White, and Grey/Ash... I used to interchange Grey and ash until I learnt the Ash was the lighter one. Nonetheless, I stuck to calling both Grey because it was my preferred word. Then I started graphic design and this is where it became interesting. What people typically call White, or Black, I'd call Grey (or sometimes light grey and dark grey) simply because it was a little bit darker than pure white, or a little bit lighter than pitch black, and it caused some confusion a few times. People hardly tell the difference, but I do. I'm also very picky about different shades of "mid-grey" because I've gotten so used to spotting the little tilts in brightness, but it's all the same to a lot of other people.

The Ancient Greeks used "cyan" (kyanos) (Wiki: "Its name is derived from the Ancient Greek κύανος, transliterated kyanos, meaning "dark blue, dark blue enamel, Lapis lazuli"".) Ancient vedic texts from India describes colour blue (nila). Example being hymns for goddess Nila (Blue coloured goddess) and hymns for god varuna (described as nila-purusha  meaning blue coloured man). Various tantric texts uses the term for blue (nila) as goddess nilapathaka (goddess of blue-flag), god Nilakantha (lord with blue-throat), sapphire as indra-nila (blue of skies), lord saturn being described as nilanjana-samabhasam (as hued as blue kohl stone) and so on. Further, blue is one of the important pigment in cave and temple murals from ancient times. Many colorblind people can't distinguish colors because their genes for the pigments that differentiate (most commonly) red and green are defective, and have a large area of overlap. If you give such people glasses which filter out a good chunk of that overlapping region, they can see the colors. Their brains didn't require any special training to differentiate those colors - it was already wired in.

two minutes in i could not help but find huge error in your, everything. "orange" is just recently introduced in most commonly used language today (it was just called "red-yellow" in english up to 500 years ago) and black, white, pink and brown are just noises and not true colours. think of them as static on your tv set that brain interprets in various ways due to intensity (amplitude) of them. also green is colour that we (humans) discern more shades of then any other colour in the specter of visible light.
you can't really talk about colours and not mention how our brain even gets that information and the fact that we have a (ridiculously named feedback loop) for colours is not that interesting when you find out that we do that with, literally, every other new information our brain gathers and deems valuable (viable for survival). think about, for example, types of swords. in times of peace we use just one word, "sword", but in medieval times that word was omitted in favor of more specialized words that conveyed more information like usage, length, material type etc.
modern example would be with computers. desktop, laptop, cellphone, tablet, smartwatch, smart tv... heck even toasters and fridges are computers but we don't call them just that and have specific neural pathways to discern them and even assign different value to them when our brain solves everyday algorithms.
will it always be so? i doubt it. brain is pretty expensive from metabolic standpoint and it does not waste parts or neural pathways. i bet that you will find some correlation between advancement of visual cultural arts and usage of more specific words for colours just like we don't use phrases "expect me to contact you via pocketable computer with microphone, speaker, camera and transciever (more precise description of cellphone)".
to find out why this is happening try learning something about brain plasticity and its evolutionary role. i bet that would blow your mind if this "colour blue" (a tiny part of it) mystery has.

I feel like this feed back loop works the same with the notion of what people call synchronicity. At first, life seems like a chaotic occurrence of random events that seemingly have not correlation to each other. As you begin to notice subtle differences, the mind can start to "link" these cause and effect cycles quicker, to the point where every little thing begins to have meaning.  I also feel like we go through cycles of this relationship building until our mind/brain needs to take break and we settle back into monotony.  Some are more geared for it than others, while some undertake too much, either through drugs, deep dives into hypnotherapy,  mental illness, or some combination of all of the above and eventually crack. Which is where we get our "crazy" from. It's not that they see the world wrong, its that they see more than what the vast majority of society is considered acceptable. Actually Homer DOES have the colour blue in it...
He uses Κυανό (Kyano) that was used for the colour of Aurichalcite from the mycenean times {this has the today maya blue, Cyan, arctic blue, baby blue}
And he also uses Γλαυκο (Ghlafko) That is the midday Sky blue to describe the quiet sea and blue eyed individuals... [that contains today's Sky blu, Cerulean, cobalt blue, Azure]
And the word for black in Homer (Melan) is black but also dark blue (Navy, Midnight, Berry, Denim)

Also in ancient greek was used the word Στιμμι. (Stimmi), a loan from ancient Egyptian s-t-b, [that passed through latin into Stibium (Antimony)] that was the grey-blue hue of Antimonite (this contained Stone blue, Spruceblue, slate blue,)

The only difference is that the ancients did not use one word for blue as we mean it today

In fact even in modern greek there is no greek word for blue. We use the french word bleu, with a greek prononciation (blé).
On the other hand we still use the ancient greek classification for cyan blue : We call it γαλάζιος galázios, meaning milky (same root as in galaxy). This is because blue was considered the same way we now consider shades of grey. Cyan was a kind of white when dark blue was seen as a kind of black.
Is may sound stupid but there are a few physical realities behind this. The spectral band of 'blue' is much larger than the bands of other colors. in other terms blue is a mix a very different frequencies of light. It's not such a selective 'color' as red or green or yellow. Therefore blue is more a shade that a color. This is so true that all the white greek houses people see in the Cyclades are usualy painted in a light blue, never with pure white.

The other physical reality is that blue is related to penetration of the light through the atmosphere and water. And boy do we have lots of water and atmosphere in Greece! So blue in our minds is associated to depth rather than a pigment.
