I'm surprised you didn't explicitly mention the Sapphir-Whorf hypothesis a.k.a. linguistic relativity.

It's the idea that the language(s) we speak fundamentally affects (influences or determines, depending on whether you're going off of the weak or strong version of the hypothesis) our worldview and cognition. Aside from colour, it also has it's effect elsewhere; if you don't have a word to describe something, it's less likely to occur as a possibility; you might still be able to understand the concept somewhat trough other terms, but you won't truly have the same option available to you.

There are some notorious words from other languages that don't exist in English, which get roughly translated but still don't really cover the full load; an example from my native language Dutch, is the word 'gezellig' (and deriviations thereof), which is sometimes translated to 'cosy' in English, and several other words ( https://en.bab.la/dictionary/dutch-english/gezellig ) but none of them really cover it, even combined, it's a concept that just doesn't exist in English, and as such it's not something that even occurs to you, whilst to Dutch people gezelligheid is a fundamental part of life and Dutch culture.

Another example I've heard in relation to this hypothesis (although I don't speak Russian and can't really check properly how accurate it is) is that in Russian there's no word for retreat (again, if you look up translations you'll get several words, but then you also see those words have a lot of different meanings in English which stray from the concept and are more general about leaving, departing, retiring, etc.), which might affect the mentality of Russian soldiers who are therefore, at least according to this hypothesis, less likely to consider retreating and instead will just keep going until the battle is won or they die.

This was fascinating.
I grasped the idea just a few seconds before he explained it, mainly because our brains think of different colours as totally different "things" but really different colours are just slightly different wavelengths of light.
It's like "can you tell the difference between light at wavelengths of 485nm and 500nm?"
It's pretty crazy that the smallest objects we can "see" are about 1/10mm but still we can distinguish differences of a few nanometres when it comes to light.
Also, red is suspiciously large in the spectrum; most colours cover a few 10s of nanometres, but red is something like 150nm. We could maybe invent a new colour and call it flaguza, between orange and red, and say it's from 620nm to 680nm.
If we convinced enough people to go along with this we could have a brand new colour, all for free.

If anyone's interested in this area, Guy Deutscher's "Through The Language Glass" is a fantastic, beautifully written, and very accessible book about language, which talks in depth about how William Gladstone (four times Prime Minister of the UK) made this discovery about Homer's colour vocabulary.

Also interesting to note that many major world languages have different numbers of "basic colour terms." Russian, for example, divides up "light blue" and "dark blue" in a way that many other languages don't - to a Russian, those aren't two shades, but two colours as distinct as yellow and green.

Also, Japan and China both historically treated "green" and "blue" as one shade, originally having only one term for each. Now they have separate words for both colours, but the green-blue confusion continues - green traffic lights in Japan are called "blue traffic lights", and are actually tinted a slight shade of blue because of this - the bluest green that can still legally be called green.

Per the color theory of light, the primary colors are red, green, and blue. The respective opposite (aka subtractive) colors are cyan, magenta, and yellow. That is, pure red is the absence of cyan; pure cyan is the absence of red. The same relationship exists between green and magenta, and blue and yellow.
Also, often light magenta is called pink rather than light red.

"Not only is our perception of the world an illusion, our brains are an active part of creating it."

Our perception of the world is not an illusion. "Illusion" can be defined as "a thing wrongly perceived by the senses". If something is wrongly perceived, then that would mean that we are not perceiving something for how it truly is. If we were to always perceive things wrongly (or if everything was an illusion as the quote of this video is claiming), then we couldn't know how any thing truly is. And if we couldn't know how any thing truly is, not only would we not have science, but we would not be able to formulate a coherent thought, because you need to be able to understand how things work in order to form coherent thoughts, and you can't understand how things work if you can't know how they truly are. Therefore, the things around us are not merely illusions that we like to categorize for the hell of it. They aren't even just mere amalgamations of particles and nothing more. No, every thing, or being, has a nature to it, or basic properties that make it what it is. We, as rational creatures, can recognize that these properties exist. And from THERE do we categorize things. And from THERE are we able to form coherent thoughts. So, we can have confidence that, although our senses can make mistakes and perceive things wrongly, the things around us are not constantly being perceived wrongly, else we would not be able to be rational creatures, which we clearly are.

words evolve and emerge by a property in linguistics called "functional load". Normally, the term is applied in phonology, but you can use the same logic to talk about word meaning as well. Simply put, the reason why a specific and unique word for blue takes longer to develop, is because blue is the colour in the environment that it least used to distinguish between things because blue was a pigment that took the longest to come under the control of humanity. Think about it this way. Imagine today but we never learned to create blue pigments, such that nothing the people produced was blue. The need to create a word for blue simply does not arise, because you're never in an instance of "hand me the bowl, the blue one, not the red one". It doesn't matter that people could look to the skies or ocean and see blue all day everyday, because there was only 1 sky and 1 ocean. I.e., you never ran into the situation where you would need to distinguish between the brown sky or the blue sky. Furthermore, day and night doesn't factor into this, because human brains are hardwired to interpret colour based on apparent lighting level. So if your brain sees a colour that it thinks is well let, versus a colour that it thinks is not well let, your brain will see them as two different shades, even if they are the same shade (this is what created the dress illusion, some people were interpreting it as a well lit dress, others were interpreting it as a dress in shade, and your brain then tried to account for this and makes you see what it believes to be the neutral colour, independent of lighting conditions).

As for categorisation, and our ability to distinguish different colours, it is true that the functional load of words impacts on this. However, studies have found that this impact is only fairly shallow, and for the most part, regardless of specific words and distinctions, human brains categorise colours all on the same general framework, and where words come in to create splits in categorisation line up with this universal framework, with same small margin of error. The margin of error being the differences this video focuses on.

30 years ago when I was living and working in Korea, I noticed that Koreans didn't distinguish green and blue.  Since I am of northern European stock, I was surprised to find that they called me pink instead of white.  Of course when I hold my hands up to the light I can understand that pink is more correct as a dead Caucasian may be more white than pink.  Color perception is interesting as is the persistence of cultural norms.  When this topic came up in my class [consisting of international students from different cultures], they had trouble with people from different places not agreeing on color.  I went around and asked them to look at my eyes and write down the color.  They thought this was dumb and expected more or less the same answer.  When some students said blue, others said green, gray or brown, some demanded a follow up look, and some asked if I had special contacts.  It was a very interesting and I hope useful class.

A similar "blue recognizing process" happened in Slavic languages.

In most Slavic languages all colours sound pretty much the same. Apart from the Blue.

Black - Slovak: Cierny, Polish, Czarny, Russian: Chorniy, Croatian: Crny
Red - Slovak: Cerveny, Polish: Czarwony, Russian: Chervlyoniy, Croatian: Crveny
White - Slovak: Biely, Polish: Bialy, Russian: Bieliy, Croatian: Bijely
Green - Slovak: Zeleny, Polish: Zielony, Russian: Zelyoniy, Croatian: Zeleny
Yellow - Slovak: Zlty, Polish: Zolty, Russian: Zyoltiy, Croatian: Zuty

Blue: Slovak: Modry (or Belasy for light blue), Polish: Niebiesky (literally 'ski-like'), Russian: Siniy for dark blue / Golubiy for light blue , Croatian: Plavy

From the above, it is obvious, that while words for the most of the existing colours existed in Slavic languages when it was still a single Proto (or Common) Slavic language, the word for blue colour appeared in Slavic languages relatively recently, after the languages split from a single Proto-Slavic language into the three main branches, i.e. West Slavic, East Slavic and South Slavic.
As this happened at about 1000 AD the word for blue exists in Slavic languages just 1000 years or less. Which really is hard to imagine that not that long ago the same nations who live in those territories now just didn't have a word for something so common like blue colour.

Unlike in Germanic languages where the word for blue existed at least (underlined) at 500 AD since the Saxons migrated to British isles at about that time and brought with them "blue" so similar to German "Blau".

Another interesting thing is that even the perception of what is "Blue" differs in Slavic languages. Or at least in Russian and Slovak.

The Russians have two words for blue: "Siniy" and "Golubiy".

Siniy means blue like the sea while Golubiy means blue like the ski. Not the English ski though ;)
Generally, Siniy is dark blue while Golubiy is light blue.

However, they perceive those two Blues as two distinct and unrelated colours.
Here is a good article about it:
https://www.pnas.org/content/104/19/7780

Similarly in Slovak:
Modry means dark blue or blue generally, while Belasy means blue like the ski. But nowadays the popularity of the word Belasy is slowly fading out in favour of Modry, perhaps under the influence of the Czech language.

Belasy looks like this:
https://i.ytimg.com/vi/djvEULbo2DM/maxresdefault.jpg

Learning to judge color variances in color transparency film (slides) takes about a week. You flip the filter over and off the image so you can make blink comparisons. Then you get really good at it and can see these variations in the world without the filters and the blink comparing. The best real world test are walls of a room, sunlit parts are warmer, blue sky lit parts are bluer... I think anyone who is not color blind can quickly learn this. One quirk. When an image is bluer (not more cyan, but more blue) it can appear darker. The big trash cans used just about everywhere in the world are called by most people 'black' I see them as 'brown'. Okay, most people call them black - I accept that. But what I find curious is that a lot of people seem really annoyed that I call them brown. That I don't understand - it's not like this would cause any confusion, like if there was a tan colored container. This sort of dissonant disagreement can also happen with greenish turquoise.

Studying chemistry, during labs my fellow students and I would often argue about the color that a certain solution might have. For example, phenolphthalein, a famous pH indicator, in an alkali solution will give out the distinct color, easily recognized by those that have spent some time in a lab. Now, for the people that were not familiar with the word "fuchsia", the phenolphthalein indicator always was some variation between red and pink and that is why we would often confuse ourselves while discussing it. Is it red? Is it pink? If you would ask a lab mate-and he or she did not know the word fuchsia- to compare the two hues (that of the phenolphthalein indicator and of a regular common red solution) he/she would find them the same. Each student would conceptualize his/her color palette in function to their own vocabulary.
Thankfully, our professors would equip us during class with a broad dictionary in Greek giving a name for every hue and eventually helping us out recognize them, to distinguish them and to be able to discuss them without confusion.

I’ve lived in the US for the last 7 years, and in that time I’ve developed a Midwestern American accent, but when reading in my mind, I still have an diluted RP British accent (which itself is weird because I grew up in Botswana). It seems that my brain has elected to use a British accent because hearing an American accent in my own head confuses me, makes it harder to understand my inner voice, and as a consequence, my mind mostly doesn’t use it.

I’ve also found that in the rare moments when I think with a Midwestern accent, my word selections are more basic and I have a harder time describing more spohisticated concepts. My girlfriend usually points out how I have a habit of using simple constructive words to explain things that have well known words or phrases. Like colors, language itself has so many subtle cues that affect how we process and contextualize information. So cool!

Worth noting that the color blue does appear quite frequently in Icelandic texts. There is a misconception that blue and black are considered the same color in old Norse, simply due to the reason that they called ravens blue. Since we today see ravens as black scholars simply decided that blue = black. The problem with that is that when you look at ravens up close, they're actually shimmering blue. This misconception is now slowly being recognized. By the way this means that Odin is described as wearing blue robes, not black. Difficult to get used to considering the modern pop culture view of him.

This is why the government in 1984 developed NuSpeak. By controlling the language they controlled the concepts that could be discussed and thus made it far more difficult for the general population to even conceive of opposing the government. If you do not have words for a concept, you cannot meaningfully convey that concept to others and likely won't recognize it if confronted with it. Instead, we try to find the closest analogy, which distorts the concept. Thus, with the right language, anything that opposes government can only be described as bad or even evil. Without the language to describe a color, then even if the difference is noticed it is likely to be dismissed as being unimportant.

The pattern is actually a bit longer, although, after that, it gets muddier and more complicated. We start of with black and white, then comes red, then yellow and green, then blue. After those come orange, purple, gray, and brown in a non-specific order (there are common patterns, but I can't remember). Next come pink and light blue.
In between those, you can get multiple new names for things more specific, without getting into some of the larger general hue names. English doesn't have a word for "light blue" even if a word for "light red" (pink) exists, plus words for specific tints of blue or blue-green such as cyan, turquoise, azure, etc. There's also the topic of having the word for a metal become the name of a color (like how we say "gold paper" instead of "golden-colored paper" or "silver paper" and not "silver-colored paper"). It'd be interesting if there's a language that's developed a separate word for metallic colors instead of just using the same words for the metals that the colors come from...

One important quibble when discussing colors. Pink is not really a shade of red. In fact, pink doesn't really exist at all. There is no wavelength of pink light. The rainbow doesn't have any pink. Pink is what your brain interprets when there is red and blue light hitting your eye but there is an absence of green light.

1:19 The bible has many colors and shades, including blue (Judea is just near Egypt, so if they had it (3:10), the jews would too); it just scarcely describes things with those colors.
White (לבן), black (שחר) and red (אדם) are the most common colors in the bible.
Green (ירק) mostly describes plants (as in Gen1:30 "I hath given thou every green plant to eat") except twice: in Lev13:49&14:37 where it describes a leper's blemish, and in Psalm68:14 where it describes gold.
Yellow (צהב) appears only in Lev13:30-36, where it describes. yet again, a leper's blemish, specifically hair.
Blue (תכלת) appears numerous times in the bible describing holy garments, as such it's a very important color in Jewish culture. In the Mishna, differentiating between blue and WHITE, or blue and green, is a sign for daybreak and that it is time for morning prayers. The Talmud also quotes rabbi Meir listing stereotypically blue stuff (the sky, the sea, and sapphire stone) to indicate blue is a very unique dye. Sapphire stone is worth mentioning, as both Ex24:10 and Ezek1:26&10:1 compare the sky to a sapphire stone and rabbi Meir quotes the latter.

Strange. In Finland, however, 'musta' (black), 'valkoinen' (white) and 'sininen' (blue) are the oldest known basic color names. 'Sininen' and its variations are used in all Ugric languages and modern scholars have suspected that the word could be a very old loanword from ancient Aryan, Iran or Mesopotamia (very similar is, for example, the Afghan word 'šin', which means 'blue'). Of course, attempts have been made to apply the theoretical model of color naming development presented by Berlin and Kay to Ugric languages, but to no avail, because the explanations are not convincing or supportive.

Oh man, I was obsessed with this concept a few months back. I'm just going to point out some of the observations I made and information I stumbled across while researching linguistic blue-green distinction.

Another possible reason for the lack of blue in certain older languages is things that are naturally blue never stay blue. The sky can be blue, but it changes significantly throughout the day. Same with the ocean. For this reason, there is never going to be a reason to distinguish blue from other colors. Also, a fascinating casual experiment was conducted where a child was raised normally but was never told the sky was blue explicitly by her parents. When asked to describe the sky, she ended up first saying it was colorless, then settling on blue only after careful contemplation, suggesting that thinking of the sky as significantly blue may be more of a social idea.

What is arguable more fascinating is how languages evolve to distinguish between blue and green. In fact, what got me into all this was after I finished my study of Chinese, and realized that like in Japanese, there was an interesting but peculiarly different way of distinguishing between green and blue.

Modern Chinese has three words of interest: 青 (qing), 绿 (lu), and 蓝 (lan). 青 is the ancient word that meant BOTH green and blue. If you asked a Chinese speaker today, they would still likely not be able to tell you if 青 meant blue or green. This is because the existence of 青 in modern Chinese exists PURELY in word phrases related to nature OR to describe nature. If you were to describe grass, the sky, a frog, water, or anything natural that is either blue OR green, you would use 青. However, if you were to describe anything synthetic, like a car, a light, a pencil, you would use either 绿 for green or 蓝 for blue. This is because the modern meaning of those two words emerged much later than 青, likely as a way of changing the language to distinguish between the two colors that caught on as the need to do so emerged. This all makes sense; because 青 is an older word, older word phrases likely include 青. And older word phrases described mainly nature, not technology. These word phrases never petered out, and thus shaped the modern usage of 青.

As most know, Japanese is heavily influenced by Chinese. However, as the two places became less and less connected, the languages spoken in each did so as well. This is, fascinatingly, reflected in the adaptation of two separate words for blue and green. Japanese handles it completely differently. In old Japanese, you would have the same character, 青 (ao), to mean either green or blue. HOWEVER, if you asked a modern Japanese speaker what 青 meant, they would tell you it means blue. Japanese evolved to distinguish by turning the old, doubly inclusive word (青) to mean only blue, and repurposing another word 緑 (midori) to mean only green. Though Japanese & Chinese originally used the same character with the same definition, they evolved to distinguish between the two colors differently. Crazy stuff.

Lastly, I would like to quickly mention that the study mentioned in the video about Himba color perception may be a bit exaggerated. This video made the wonderful and accurate distinction that the study measured reaction time, not success vs failure, which is often omitted in order to to make the study's results seem more shocking and dramatic. I won't go into detail here, but you can read up on why the study is a bit sketchy here: https://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=18237

I hope this was at least interesting to read!

Your final point reminds me of the story of Nicaraguan Sign Language which was spontaneously created by a group of deaf children at a newly opened special ed school to communicate with each other. Later generations of students added more complexity to the language and when researchers compared the abilities of the first gen with later students, the older group struggled more on tests for spatial awareness and recognizing others' mental states which strongly suggests having words for something fundamentally changes the way we think about those things.

They probably saw blue, but they all associated blue with things we associate with other colors. For example, if an ancient writing translated to “the color of an apple”, we would think of red. But if someone in the time of that writing were to read it, they would think of blue. Apples could have changed colors due to evolution.

I’m not saying apples were blue. My point is that they could have seen blue the same way we do, but due to changes between our time periods, the things that used to be blue are not blue anymore.

It’s like if two people went to the same market at different times. One person might say the bananas are green. Another person could go to the market a week later and say the bananas are yellow. They both saw the bananas, but because they saw them at different times, they saw different colors.

Also, I do not know if this applies to all slavonic languages, but in my native tongue (Slovak), we have a different word for light blue and (regular) blue. Light blue = belasá, normal blue = modrá. Dark blue = tmavá modrá (literally dim blue). The belasá is not cyan. Cyan is tyrkysová, based on the Turquoise mineral. Also, the color brown does not exist. It is, technically speaking, a dim orange. But even english has a different word for orange and brown. Think of it that Slovak has a different word for light blue (belasá, like orange) and blue (modrá, like brown). The distinction is similar, regarding the lightness of the color, not its tone. Orange is lighter, so lighter blue is belasá, brown is darker, so darker blue is modrá (modrá being the equivalent of blue). Of course we have word for brown (hnedá) and orange (oranžová) as well.

I've noticed that feedback loop with vehicles oddly enough. I don't notice different vehicles too much, they just all sort of blend together. The only ones that really stand out to me are vehicles from pop culture like the Back to the Future Delorian, VW Beetles because of G1 Bumblebee and Herbie the love bug, Cameros also because of Bumblebee but a different version of the character. Despite Cameros existing for YEARS like the first Camero Bumblebee transforms into is from the 70's but I never noticed that this car existed till 2007 when that movie came out. The other way I recognize vehicles is because a friend or someone in my family happen to own that particular vehicle at some point. I'll start noticing and seeing the vehicle everywhere. I figured it was because I was actively looking for that particular vehicle in parking lots but the same is not true for cars like the Camero as no I know has ever owned one but I still see them everywhere. I also thought maybe it's because those vehicles become more popular around the time those movies came out but I've found there are people who don't know about Transformers but still own a Camero with that exact color scheme like in the movie just by sheer coincidence. It's kind of like the "eth" VS "thorn" difference in language. These are two characters used in older versions of English to produce the "th" sound, but they're different from each other. Eth is more of a "d" sound (sometimes specified with dh instead) produced by biting your tongue between your teeth, whereas thorn is the traditional "th" sound we generally think of produced by barely touching your teeth. Eth is far more common than we realize, but it isn't until you learn to listen for it that you notice a difference, or can even hear the difference. For clarity, I will change all eths with "dh" and write this same paragraph below.

It's kind of like dhe "edh" VS "thorn" difference in language. Dhese are two characters used in older versions of English to produce dhe "th" sound, but dhey're different from each odher. Edh is more of a "d" sound produced by biting your tongue between your teeth, whereas thorn is the traditional "th" sound we generally think of produced by barely touching your teeth. Edh is far more common dhan we realize, but it isn't until you learn to listen for it dhat you notice a difference, or can even hear dhe difference. According to Mahadevan, the phrase Nil Kanta is the phonetic value of the Indus sign pair meaning "great personage" in proto dravidian language. This title when borrowed in to Indo-Aryan as a load word with only minimal phonetic changes has changed its meaning to Nila Kanta which means "Blue Neck" in Indo-Aryan. Concurrently, the meaning of the derived title nīlkanta passed into Indo Aryan as a loan translation, Mahādeva, ‘great god’. Both the loanword and the loan translation refer to Shiva who had emerged as the ‘great god’ in this period. The Indo-Aryans created these myths around 2000 BCE which is more than 4000 years ago

Hmmm. In ancient Chinese, 蓝 , more than 2000 Years ago, blue was named as 青，which stands for blue, green and blueish greenish black.
《说文》 “蓝，染青草也” means: blue, the grass that can dye the color blue. The character has the radical “艹”, which stands for grass. The word blue came directly from the grass which leaves can be used to dye the color blue.
AT the time of XunZi. (313B. C. -238B. C. ), “青出于蓝而胜于蓝”, 蓝 is still the name of the grass, and the color blue is named after 青.
But from Wei Jin and Southern Northern dynasty, (220-420) there are already documents using the word 蓝 directly to refer the color. But it didn’t make into the dictionaries. Means people already use this word to refer the color blue at the daily use but was still not recognized officially. 梁·江淹《杂体诗序》：“譬犹蓝朱成彩，杂错之变无穷。”
From Tang Dynasty（618-907）, 蓝 was commonly used to refer as the color, 杜甫《冬到金华山观》诗：“上有蔚蓝天，垂光抱琼台。” 蓝 means exactly as the blue we are talking about today.

Once a well-known organ transplant expert in China, Shen Zhongyang was recently purged by the Chinese communist regime and removed from the National Committee of China’s Political Consultative Conference.

Shen was a former director of the Center for Organ Transplantation in Tianjin Central First Hospital and the Liver Transplant Institute of Armed Police General Hospital. On the Tianjin Central First Hospital’s official website, Shen was introduced as “a renowned organ transplant expert.”

According to the hospital’s website, “In 1998, he established the first organ transplant institute and trained many organ transplant workers. He led the team to assist nearly 70 medical units in the country to perform liver transplantation. In 20 years, he and his team completed more than 10,000 liver transplants.”

On the website of China’s United Front Work Department, it says that under Shen’s leadership, the Central First Hospital performed 5,000 liver transplants by 2010.

Another introduction about Shen on a Baidu Baike (Baidu Encyclopedia) page, it states that Shen completed almost 10,000 liver transplants by 2014, making up a quarter of the country’s total liver transplant cases.

Shen’s involvement in such a high-volume of organ transplants reveals a dark, state-sanctioned crime in China––the killing of Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience for their organs.

The History of Organ Harvesting
Unlike many countries with established organ donation systems, China doesn’t have one. Due to the influence of traditional culture, Chinese people prefer to keep their bodies intact after death and not many of them embrace the idea of organ donations introduced by Western medicine.

It was known that the Chinese communist regime was using organs from death row prisoners for the transplants needed by high-ranking officials. But due to the limited number of prisoners and the health conditions of their organs, this was only done on a small scale.

After the Chinese communist regime ordered the persecution of Falun Gong, a mind and body practice, since July 1999, the number of organ transplants skyrocketed. In April 2006, the ex-wife of a surgeon who was involved in removing organs from living Falun Gong practitioners came forward to expose the crimes to the world.

Ongoing Investigation
Since then, human rights activists have been investigating this horrendous crime of organ harvesting from living individuals.

In July 2006, David Kilgour, former Canadian Secretary of State for Asia-Pacific, and David Matas, Canadian human rights lawyer, released a 45-page report, concluding “...the government of China and its agencies in numerous parts of the country, in particular hospitals but also detention centres and 'people's courts', since 1999, have put to death a large but unknown number of Falun Gong prisoners of conscience. Their vital organs, including hearts, kidneys, livers and corneas, were virtually simultaneously seized for sale at high prices, sometimes to foreigners, who normally face long waits for voluntary donations of such organs in their home countries.”

In June 2016, together with Ethan Gutmann, a US investigative writer, the three of them released an updated investigative report on the forced organ harvesting in China. They looked into hundreds of hospitals in China and learned that they offered their patients transplants in a couple of weeks after they “placed the order.” This could only be done when there was an enormous pool of organ supply.

Their investigations also showed that the actual number of transplants performed each year by a few Chinese hospitals had exceeded the officially reported number of total transplants in the nation, which was between 10,000 to 15,000 each year. The shockingly high number of organs transplanted between 2006 to 2016 came mainly from Falun Gong practitioners arrested and incarcerated for refusing to give up their faith, according to the report.

On June 13, 2016, the US House unanimously passed Resolution 343, which called on China to “immediately end the practice of organ harvesting from all prisoners of conscience.” It asked China to end the 17-year persecution of Falun Gong and release all Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience. It also demanded the CCP to “allow a credible, transparent, and independent investigation into organ transplant abuses.” Last but not least, it called on the US State Department to report annually to Congress on the implementation of barring provision of visas to Chinese and other nationals engaged in coerced organ or bodily tissue transplantation.

Matas, Kilgour, and Gutmann were invited to a hearing at the European Parliament on June 29, 2016, and presented their updated report on China’s systemic organ harvesting. They urged the EU to take action to stop the atrocity.

According to Matas, the final conclusion drawn from the investigations was that the CCP had forced the entire country to take part in the large-scale murder. The victims were mainly Falun Gong practitioners, he said, as well as Uygurs, Tibetans, and house church members. The CCP’s crackdown on them was a means to obtain organs for transplants, he said.

As Matas pointed out, when there is a large-scale crime committed and tens of thousands were killed, the number of perpetrators was no less than that of the victims. He named a few: those who performed the tests on Falun Gong practitioners’ blood and organs, the prison guards who brought in the practitioners, the doctors and nurses who performed the transplant surgeries, the agents of the 610 Office who were in charge of the persecution, and those who spread hatred against the practitioners.

An independent people’s tribunal, known as the China Tribunal, in its final judgment delivered in London on June 17, 2019, said that there was clear evidence that forced organ harvesting has taken place in China for years “on a significant scale.”

While the Chinese regime has maintained from 2015 that organ transplants have come from voluntary donors, the tribunal said it concluded the practice is still taking place. The panel said it was certain that the organs were sourced from imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners, who were “probably the principal source.”

“The conclusion shows that very many people have died indescribably hideous deaths for no reason, [and] that more may suffer in similar ways,” tribunal chairman Sir Geoffrey Nice QC said in delivering the judgment on June 17.

The international panel reached its conclusions after considering a variety of written and oral statements, including testimony from more than 50 witnesses given over the course of two public hearings.

Mathematics & Astronomy Professor Peter W. Stoner has made the statement that the
chances of just 8 prophecies (like these) coming true by sheer chance is 1 in 10¹⁷(100,000,000,000,000,000). That would be equivalent to covering the whole state of Texas with silver dollars two feet deep and then expecting a blindfolded man to walk across the state and on the very first try find the ONE coin you marked (roughly equivalent to the Province of Ontario being 1.5 feet deep).
And if we were to add only 8 more similar prophecies, for a total of 16, the odds would be 1 x 10²⁸ x 10¹⁷ or 1 in 10⁴⁵ (1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000)
Using the same type of illustration as above, if we were to press this many silver dollars(10⁴⁵) into a ball and place the center of this ball where the center of our Sun is, this silver ball's outer edge would be in approximately the same area as the orbit of Neptune (almost to Pluto.). One man fulfilling all 16 prophecies by sheer chance would be like sending a blind-folded person out to find one specific silver dollar that has been marked and has been mixed up somewhere in this huge ball and actually finding it the first time! (Keep in mind that this is a three-dimensional BALL, not a disk like our Solar System.)

Professor Stoner gives us yet another illustration, but this time, because a silver dollar, and even the atom, would be too large for this one he chose to use just the electron that orbits the nucleus of the atom.  The electron is one of the smallest particles of matter known to man. It is so small that if you lined up 2.5 x 10¹⁵ (2,500,000,000,000,000) single file you would end up with a line that is only 1 inch long. (If we were going to count the electrons in this line one inch long, and counted 250 each minute, and if we counted day and night, it would take us 19,000,000 years to count just the one-inch line of electrons.)
Now back to Stoner's illustration. Using only 48 of the prophecies that Jesus fulfilled it was
calculated that the chances of one person fulfilling these by sheer chance would be 1 in 10¹⁵⁷To help us understand how huge this number is he suggested taking 10¹⁵⁷ electrons and pressing them into a solid ball. This ball, made entirely of electrons, would pretty much fill, not just our galaxy, but the entire known universe. (At the time Stoner's book was written the universe was known to be at least 6 billion light years in all directions. Stoner's known universe would need to be filled about 10,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 times.) Once again we would mark just one electron, blindfold a man and send him out to find that one electron. Peter Stoner then states, "To the extent, then, that we know this blindfolded man cannot pick out the marked electron, we know that the Bible is inspired. This is not merely evidence. It is proof of the Bible's inspiration by God--proof so definite that the universe is not large enough to hold the evidence." Professor Stoner then made the comment that, "Any man who rejects Christ as the Son of God is rejecting a fact proved perhaps more absolutely than any other fact in the world."

This phenomenon isn't limited to just the identification of various colors. There's a linguistic theory called the Whorf-Sapir theory, otherwise known as linguistic relativity, which states that a person's language directly influences the way they perceive the world around them. Benjamin Lee Whorf spent many years in the field studying different indigenous American language and found that in particular the Hopi have no perception or understanding of things like tenses, spatial metaphors for time ("ahead" vs. "behind"), no discrete units of time like "day" and "week," and didn't even have much appreciation for the notion of time itself - because their language completely lacks the words to describe those things.

There are languages from native tribes that do not have left and rights, instead they use the cardinal directions (NESW) when they great each other they say "in which direction are you heading" and they would respond something along the lines of "in the North North east directions how about you" This gives many of the people a constant sense of direction at a young age. Normally we organize time from left to right with ourselves as the center,(for example organize pictures from youngest to oldest people) but these people because of how their language affects their cognition organize time from east to west with the earth as the orgin because of the rising and setting of the sun.
Certain languages do not have counting systems or have multiple names for colors that are the same for us, like with the russians and light/dark blue being two distinctive words. These aspects of language have a large affect on how they percieve the world.

Just to point out there are some valid critiques of the "wine-dark sea" statement. Much of the modern labels for most colors come from the industrialization of the pigment market, so in antiquity the description of something as "red" could've range from deep maroon or crimson, a vibrant vermilion, or even the pastel: pink- completely up to the author's subjectivity. Another idea that has been put forth is the state of the Aegean Sea at the time because several species of algae, when blooming, can dramatically alter the color of the water ranging from sickly green, bright pink, or even dark red. Also another belief behind the "wine-dark sea" description has to do with the color of wine. Wine fermentation was not an expert level craft prior to understanding of the fermentation process and the reliable ability to control temperature over a long period of time. Wine producing cultures often mixed wine with other substances to improve taste and to aid in preservation, like the Romans added a compound of lead to sweeten the flavor. Changing the pH of wine can have a significant effect on it's color as in adding in hard water can make wine appear more bluish in color.

This description is somewhat inaccurate.  Blue is not the "last" color word.  We have well-identified color words in our culture like Purple, Orange, Brown, and Pink, all of which entered later (in that order).  The process continues.   And this isn't arbitrary.  Those words aren't similar to things like "periwinkle".  Shown something pink, someone in our culture would call it pink, and think it very strange to call it anything else like red, even though it is a red with some white in it.  When shown brown, we would think it's very weird to call it orange even though in another lighting it would be an orange.    This cultural idea of colors shifts over time and is sitll doing so.

It's kinda like music and specific notes. Most never learn to distinguish notes one from another until late in life, but those who do learn at very early infancy often times are able to distinguish all notes on everything (not necessarily an instrument). Sound is just another type of wave anyway. Frequencies with distinct waves we just don't learn to separate. Same with colour. We learn to differentiate them and that gives context depending on how many we learn.

In the 1980s, when I was repairing a spectroscope for my high school (long story.) I looked at the solar spectrum, and the spectrum of a fluorescent light. When I was looking at bright spectral lines on a dark background, I would call them all the different colours: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, or violet. I have good colour vision btw. But when I was seeing the WHOLE solar spectrum with dark lines, or a spectrum of a lightbulb, I would basically see the red part, and the green-blue part. Except for a very narrow area, all the warm yellows and oranges would kind of blend with red, and all the "acid" yellows and yellow-greens would blend at the green end of the continuous green-blue wash. I am not sure why, but it may have something to do with the fact that yellow is a very distinct shade for me, while cyan is just any old mix of green and blue. So yes, I agree with what was said. Having a strong idea of what a colour looks like, makes it easy to distinguish, while not having such a crisp category caused it to blend with its neighbours.

In Hungarian we have three words for red. Piros, vörös and bordó. We call "piros" mostly artificial things like a red ball, traffic light, but also lighter shades of red in general. On the other hand we call "vörös" mostly natural thing, like blood, wine, red hair color, fox's fur, etc.  Lastly, we call "bordó" the very dark, almost brown/black spectrum of red. It's interesting for me, that we have three distinct words for the color red.

Alternatively what Homer meant by "Copper colored sky" was exactly that. We tend to encounter and imagine metals in their clean, manufactured forms with no oxidation. When you say "steel" you think about a grey metal. When you say "copper" you think about the brown/yellow metal. However, the greeks were much more used to copper as a utility metal.
Their lamps, decorations, vessels, jewelry; a lot of it would be made of copper.
And copper oxidizes.
If you expose copper to salty sea air, you get green/blue verdigris colors (Statue of Liberty)
If you expose copper to sulfur, you get a dark black (think any modern bronze statues in parks throughout the US)
If you expose copper to ammonia, you get this very vibrant blue with hints of green.
These wouldn't have been unusual either. Leave copper on your building in the mediterranean, and you get verdigris. Work with copper in making tools or doing ceremonies, it's going to contact sulfur. Piss in a copper chamberpot or dye clothes with urea, you're going to get ammonia.

Looks like the dye translated as blue in ancient Hebrew really was blue colored:

The early rabbinic literature in turn provide two main expositions for the color of techelet. One group of sources, including Bava Metziya 61a-b and Menachot 40a-b, mentions qala ilan, an indigo dye described as visually indistinguishable from tekhelet. Yet, although this dye was much cheaper to obtain, the rabbis cursed those who substituted techelet with some low-priced equivalent and in fact preferred to annul the obligation altogether rather than to compromise its value (Mishnah Menachot 4:1), which clearly proves that it was not the color which mattered most. The second and much more numerous group compares the tekhelet to the color of the sky or the sea which is not far off from indigo.

But that's not to say it was a recognized color independent of the dying process.

While those are almost universal, there may be languages that lack any fixed colour terms whatsoever. Pirahã is the prime example, having words for "light" and "dark", but nothing beyond that. But then, Pirahã also lacks a concept of numerals beyond "few" and "many". Such a strange language. :)

If you look at the etymology of the word "blue", it entered via Proto-Germanic *blēwaz ("blue, dark blue"), which itself came from Proto-Indo-European *bʰlēw ("yellow, blond, gray"). There was no specific PIE word for the colour we call "blue", it was just a grayish hue of yellow.
